result.description:
Summary:

The “timezone” variable from libc is not usable in the iOS Simulator. It works properly on a real iOS device and in desktop Mac OS X.

Steps to Reproduce:

Build and run this program. You can do this for the iOS Simulator, an iOS device, and desktop Mac OS X.

--
#import <Foundation/Foundation.h>
#include <time.h>

int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
  NSLog(@"Before: %d", timezone);
  tzset();
  NSLog(@"After: %d", timezone);
  return 0;
}
--

Expected Results:

The expected “after” value is 18000 in New York and 28800 in Cupertino. The value should be the number of seconds west of UTC during standard (not daylight) time for the currently selected time zone. This is 5 * 60 * 60 in New York and 8 * 60 * 60 in Cupertino.

Actual Results:

The iOS device (4.3) and desktop OS (10.6.7) both report the proper “after” value. For me, this is 18000, because my system is configured to use New York as the time zone.

The iOS simulator (4.3) shows both 1474660693 for the “before” and “after” values.

Regression:

None that I can see, although it is an unnecessary area of divergence between the iOS device and simulator targets.

Notes:

This bug is caused by the simulator’s libSystem (libc) design, which overlays ….sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib on top of the host system’s /usr/lib/libSystem.dylib. Other similar bugs may be present, the one I’m reporting relates to the use of the “timezone” variable.

In the iOS (and iOS Simulator) SDK’s <sys/cdefs.h>, there is no non-UNIX2003 mode for source code at all. iOS is always UNIX2003. This is controlled by the __DARWIN_ONLY_UNIX_CONFORMANCE macro. Thus, according to <time.h>, there should only be a timezone variable, and no timezone(int, int) function, because __DARWIN_UNIX03 is always be defined for iOS and the iOS Simulator. At the binary level, libSystem (libc) only offers timezone in the data section in the iOS device SDK; this is the timezone variable. There is no timezone(int, int) function. However, the design of libSystem (libc) for the iOS simulator target presents a timezone symbol in the text section.

mark@selecty bash$ nm /Developer/Platforms/iPhoneSimulator.platform/Developer/SDKs/iPhoneSimulator4.3.sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib | grep timezone
0000d298 T _timezone

T for Text. There isn’t any corresponding declaration for this timezone function, but it’s present in the Simulator’s ….sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib. This libSystem.dylib itself relies on ….sdk/usr/lib/system/libSystem.host.dylib, which is a symbolic link to the real native /usr/lib/libSystem.dylib. That means that compiled code is expecting to see a timezone variable according to this declaration:

extern long timezone;

but ld actually resolves “timezone” as the text symbol, which is a timezone function. There’s no error or warning because the linker had no idea that the source expected “timezone” in a specific section, it simply resolves symbols by name, and it finds the one in the text section first because that’s what’s present in ….sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib.

The value of timezone in the simulator is always 1474660693 (when you expect 18000). This isn’t a function pointer, it’s the first few instructions of the timezone function.

This all became clear to me when I printed 1474660693 in hexadecimal. It’s 0x57e58955. That looks very much like an x86 function prologue.

While debugging this, I found dladdr to be handy. Noting that the value of “daylight” was correct while the value of “timezone” was not, I wrote:

Dl_info dli;
int dlr = dladdr(&timezone, &dli);
NSLog(@"timezone dlr=%d fname=%s fbase=%p sname=%s saddr=%p", dlr, dli.dli_fname, dli.dli_fbase, dli.dli_sname, dli.dli_saddr);

dlr = dladdr(&daylight, &dli);
NSLog(@"daylight dlr=%d fname=%s fbase=%p sname=%s saddr=%p", dlr, dli.dli_fname, dli.dli_fbase, dli.dli_sname, dli.dli_saddr);

and noted the difference in output:

timezone dlr=1 fname=/Developer/Platforms/iPhoneSimulator.platform/Developer/SDKs/iPhoneSimulator4.3.sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib
fbase=0xcae000 sname=timezone saddr=0xcbb298
daylight dlr=1 fname=/usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib fbase=0x90a5b000
sname=daylight saddr=0xa00a67b4

Note the difference between the fname for each. timezone is coming from ….sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib as opposed to the host’s /usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib, but ….sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib exposes timezone as a text symbol, not data.

And finally:

mark@selecty bash$ gdb -q
(gdb) file /Developer/Platforms/iPhoneSimulator.platform/Developer/SDKs/iPhoneSimulator4.3.sdk/usr/lib/libSystem.dylib
[...]
(gdb) disas timezone timezone+4
Dump of assembler code from 0xd298 to 0xd29c:
0x0000d298 <timezone+0>:        push   %ebp
0x0000d299 <timezone+1>:        mov    %esp,%ebp
0x0000d29b <timezone+3>:        push   %edi
End of assembler dump.
(gdb) x/1 timezone
0xd298 <timezone>:      0x57e58955

There’s the phantom value.
result.title: Can’t use “timezone” variable (libc) in iOS Simulator

result.description:
Summary:

Users currently have to click on a support link within a product's iTunes page, which may or may not go anywhere useful. In the best of cases, these support systems require the user to navigate a foreign UI to have their problem resolved.

Many users skip this option entirely and instead use ratings and reviews to voice their issues, polluting an app's user reviews and possibly unfairly diminishing its rating (especially in the case of enhancement requests). Worst of all, developers have no way to contact these users.

Instead, I request that bug reporting and feature requesting be made part of the iTunes App Store and Mac App Store experiences, allowing users to communicate directly with developers about their troubles and wish lists without requiring a new set of credentials or learning new UI on third-party sites. All bugs should be sent to individual developers, with the option to have the user's ID be hidden (and emails sent on their behalf by Apple) for the sake of privacy.

Thank you.
result.title: Bug Reports in iTunes and Mac App Store

result.description:
Summary:
Location Services options appear under Settings - General - Restrictions - Allow Changes.
Mail, Contacts, Calendar options does not appear under Settings - General - Restrictions - Allow Changes.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go to Settings - General - Restrictions 
2. Enter your passcode and scroll down to Allow Changes.
3a. Tap on Locations.
3b. Go back and tap on Accounts. 

Expected Results:
3a. Allow Changes/Don't Allow Changes options appear together with Location Services options.
3b. Allow Changes/Don't Allow Changes options appear together with Mail, Contacts, Calendar options. 

Actual Results:
Mail, Contacts, Calendar Options does not appear under 3b above. 

Regression:
With Restrictions enabled, users who need to make changes to their Mail, Contacts, Calendar options will need to perform the following:
1. Go to Settings - General - Restrictions
2. Enter passcode to proceed.
3. Scroll down to Allow Changes.
4. Tap on Accounts, followed by Allow Changes.
5. Go back up three levels. 
6. Tap on Mail, Contacts, Calendars.
7. Tap on an account and make relevant changes.
8. Go back one level.
9. Tap on General - Restrictions.
10. Enter passcode to proceed. 
11. Scroll down to Allow changes.
12. Tap on Accounts, followed by Don't Allow Changes.

Notes:
As you can see, there are too many steps involved just to make changes to any Mail, Contacts, Calendar settings when Restrictions are enabled. A user may forget to switch back to Don't Allow Changes once they have made changes to their Mail, Contacts, Calendar settings. It would be a convenience if the relevant sections appear under Settings - General - Restrictions - Accounts - Allow Changes.

result.description:
(I am reporting an issue in the Czech locazation. The usual description format does not seem appropriate, so I do not follow it.)

Issue description: The term "disk image" is currently translated as "bitová kopie" or "bitová kopie disku" in the Czech localization of Mac OS X. (The localization appears in the Disk Utility and elsewhere.) Instead the simple and straightforward translation "obraz disku" ("disk image") should be used. "Bitová kopie disku" means "bit copy of a disk". Most users, however, do not know what a bit copy is, moreover a "disk image" is not a bit copy (it may *contain* a bit copy of a disk).

Possible problems: In the Disk Utility, "bitová kopie" is likely to be misunderstood as creation of an exact copy of a disk (on another disk), while in other context many users will not understand it at all (such as in Safari preferences).

Notes: As far as I know there is no ambiguity in "obraz disku" and the term is commonly used in Czech in Mac, Windows and Unix/Linux environment. I also believe that it has been used in earlier Mac OS X localizations.

result.description:
Short version - please add an option when sending local or push notifications to select how a notification is to be displayed to the user, such as a "notificationDisplayType" property

Long version - With the addition of Notification Center in iOS 5, the Stocks and Weather widgets have shown how it can be used as the perfect place for an application to quickly display a content summary to a user without them having to open the app. Such an example is a sporting application wanting to send constant push notifications to signify a change in the score in a game of football. If this were to happen, the user would be overwhelmed with constant popups every time the score changes, which would be too much to handle. However, this could be greatly improved if an application could send such notifications just to Notification Center, so users can start to use it a "widget-style" system as they are about to do with Stocks and Weather. 

My suggestion is to add a property named "notificationDisplayType" or similar to control how the notification is presented to the user. Such a property could appear as an option when setting up a UILocalNotification and as a possible property in the JSON payload for a push notification. This would greatly enhance the capability of Notification Center, as well as removing the need to give developers the tools to create widgets.

Summary:

Depends on level of encryption selected in step 3.
- With "prefer on": Login screen is uninteractive, except user icons look clickable after first click event.

- With "always on": Error - "Unable to connect to VNC Server using your chosen security setting. Either upgrade VNC Server to a more recent version from RealVNC Ltd, or select a weaker level of encryption."

RealVNC was able to view Screen Sharing correctly in Snow Leopard, if I remember correctly.

result.title: RealVNC client can not log in to Lion VNC

result.description:
Summary:
For normal attributes and one-to-one relationships you get a
"-validate<Key>:error:" when you ask CoreData for the implementations
of the accessors, however on a (one/many)-to-many relationship you only get
"-add<Key>sObject:" and "-remove<Key>sObject:". 
This makes it pretty much impossible to validate newly added/removed relationships.

To allow entities to refuse relationships to certain managed objects based on defined conditions one needs an equivalent of "-validate<Key>:error:" for to-many relationships.

Steps to Reproduce:
Have an entity Foo with a to-many relationships with managed objects whose property self.foobar is required to be equal to @"bar" when added in order to be allowed a relationship with Foo. Or just about any other condition.

Expected Results:
There exist two additional validation methods for use prior to addition and removal of managed objects from a to-many relationship.

Actual Results:
There exist no such methods.
Apparently the only currently available solution is to either have them fail silently in "-add<Key>sObject:" and "-remove<Key>sObject:".
Or to re-validate every single relationship in "-validate<Key>:error:" one at a time. Out of potentially 100.000+. Big waste of CPU cycles, memory (thousands of avoidable faults) and last but not least brain work.
Further more there's no straight-forward way to at that time find out which element was changed and whether it was removed or added.

Regression:

Notes:
Found a 6 year old osx dev mailing list post by Karl Adam from 2005 asking for the very same thing: http://www.cocoabuilder.com/archive/cocoa/143948-validating-new-entity-in-one-to-many-relationships-in-core-data.html
Unfortunately he didn't file a report back then.
result.title: KVC Validation methods missing for Core-Data to-many-relationships or in general

result.description:
Summary:

When playing an MP3 file from a remote URL using AVFoundation, periodic NSTimer calls are substantially delayed when the media is loading.  The delay is always present, but its length increases when precise timing is requested, and also when the server provides the file slowly.

Steps to Reproduce:

A sample project is attached which reproduces the problem.  It was created as follows:

1. Schedule an NSTimer instance on the main run loop at an interval of 0.1 seconds.

2. Use AVFoundation classes to load and play remote media as described here:

http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/AudioVideo/Conceptual/AVFoundationPG/Articles/02_Playback.html

3. Within the selector called by the timer, access the duration property of the asset.

4. Monitor the interval between timer firings, reporting it if it is more than 50% longer than the requested interval.

Expected Results:

The timer will continue to fire within a reasonable margin of the requested interval, possibly reporting an unknown duration.

Actual Results:

In the best case, where the server provides the media quickly or precise timing is not requested, the timer will be delayed once for about 1 second, which might be noticeable to the user but not egregious.

If precise timing is requested, the timer will be delayed once for around 20 seconds for a 12 minute MP3, and generally this delay seems proportional to the file's size.

If the precise timing is requested and the server provides the media slowly (this is not included in the attached example), the timer will be delayed for a period that varies with the length of the server's speed.  To demonstrate this, I set up my server to sleep for a varying amount of time after transmitting each 8k block or part thereof.  With precise timing requested, and loading a 90 second clip, the results are as follows:

per-block server delay (in seconds) => client delay (in seconds)
0.1 =>  7
0.2 => 12
0.3 => 18
0.4 => 24
0.5 => The asset fails to load.

Without precise timing requested, the delay is more constant:
0.1 => 0.9
0.2 => 0.7
0.3 => 0.7
0.4 => 0.6
0.5 => 0.8

Regression:

Not known.

Notes:

This can cause trouble for audio players that update their interfaces using an NSTimer.  For instance, an app might want to show loading progress for a clip.  It would be better if an unknown duration did not block the app from updating.
result.title: AVFoundation classes block NSTimer when precise timing is requested

result.description:
(Sorry for not strictly following the description format. It is not suitable in this case.)

Summary:

"OK" (the confirmation button label) is currently left untranslated in the Czech localization. In previous versions of Mac OS (since System 6 if I remember correctly) it has been translated as "Budiž", which is in my opinion more suitable in Czech than "OK". Additionally, using "Budiž" would be consistent with previous Mac OS X localizations.

Discussion:

While "OK" is certainly comprehensible to any Czech user, out of the computer context, the word is used only as slang. To confirm something with an "OK" is very colloquial and so it does not match the level of formality in Mac OS X interface. "Budiž" is a Czech word that can be used for confirmation in any context in which Mac OS X uses "OK".

Frequency and context of usage of the words "OK" (pronounced "oukej", "ou kej", or "ó ká" in Czech) and "budiž" in a current Czech spoken corpus from primary and secondary school lessons[1] reveals that:

- OK is used only three times: in two classes, in both cases to explain which button to use in a software where "OK" wasn't translated:

http://box.nohejl.name/lev/budiz-diskuse/schola2010-OK.png

(Translation: "set up. be careful not to press 'oukej', because that would take you back again", "set up and confirm. now confirm using 'oukej', close, close the whole dialog.", "so here you will have a table. then use 'oukej'. And then you will have the field here from which you can".)

- Budiž is used four times in four different classes, in one case in a citation of a literary work, but otherwise it occurs in the sentence naturally to confirm or approve something:

http://box.nohejl.name/lev/budiz-diskuse/schola2010-budiz.png

(Translation: "inner life of the main character, alright, 'budiž'. I'm listening to you. ...", then the literary quotation, "that's not a daily but a weekly newspaper, 'budiž' nonetheless. What else? ...", "movement. blender? blender. blender, alright, 'budiž' blender. washmashine. washmashine, alright, washmashine")

Budiž should be comprehensible to anyone, and can be used in formal and informal context. (I have chosen the spoken corpus from schools, which I believe provides the right level of formality, to prove the point. In newspapers, "budiž" would be even more common, and "OK" virtually absent except for quotations of slang and computer interface elements.) 

Another argument is that "Budiž" has been used in Czech Mac OS localizations up until now and long-time Mac users are used to it. The only possible argument against "Budiž" is that other software than Mac OS (X) and devices commonly use "OK", so people are used to seeing "OK" in the computer context often even if the rest of the interface is translated to Czech. But even for these people Budiž should not be confusing, it is a clear, unambigous, and relatively common (see corpus citations above) word.

References:

[1] Czech National Corpus/Český národní korpus - SCHOLA2010. Ústav Českého národního korpusu FF UK, Praha 2010. Available online: <http://www.korpus.cz>.
result.title: Translation of "OK" in the Czech localization

June 11:

I've checked the latest preview update (Mac OS X Lion Developer Preview 4 Build 11A480b), and the window title has indeed changed. Now it reads "Schránka nevybrána". There are two reasons why I think that this is not appropriate:

1. It's an awkward constructions. As I have said a natural way to say this is "Není označená (vybraná) žádná schránka".

2. The verb "vybrat" in conjunction with the terse formulation suggests this meaning "(the contents of) the mailbox have not been taken out", which would likely mean that no messages were downloaded. In normal speech "vybrat schránku" means to get mail out of a mailbox.

This is connected with radar #9441516, in which I explain why "select" should be translated as "označit", not as "vybrat". If you use "označit" in this case, the terse formulation (schránka neoznačena) at least won't be ambiguous (but it will still be very awkward).

I'd suggest (1) using a longer formulation for the window title and (2) reevaluating the translation of "select" in Mac OS X. The usage of "Vybrat" will inevitably lead to similar confusion elsewhere.
result.title: Awkward window title in Czech localization of Mail

result.description:
Summary: The word click is translated as "kliknout" (verb), "kliknutí" (noun), and the word "double-click" as "poklikání". The former, although not used except for computer slang, may be a matter of taste, the latter ("poklikání") sounds ridiculous. Possible alternatives are "klepnout, klepnutí, poklepání" or "kliknout, kliknutí, dvojité kliknutí".

Discussion: The word "kliknout" and derived words is often used in Czech for English "click" in the computer context, it's a widely used slang and comprehensible to anyone with some experience with computers. The corresponding slang for "double-click" is "dvojklik / dvojité kliknutí" (noun), "kliknout dvakrát" (verb). Poklikání sounds very weird. Former Czech Mac OS localizations since System 6 have used the words "klepnout" and "poklepat" (tap, tap two or more times, respectively). This was a very natural choice that avoided slang (anything with "klik"), awkward or non-existing words with funny associations ("poklikání" associates "popukání", "pokakání", "poblinkání", informal words for laughter, excrements and vomit), and I believe that it was universally comprehensible. "Kliknutí", while informal, will be comprehensible to people that already have experience with computers and know the English word "click". So choice between the two may be a matter of taste, but if for some reason you want to change "poklepat" to "kliknout", it would be better to use "kliknout dvakrát", "dvojité kliknutí" and certainly not "poklikání".
result.title: Translation of "click" in the Czech localization

result.description:
Summary:

The word "Select" and derived words (as in "Select All", "Selected", "Selection") is translated as "Vybrat" ("Vybrat vše", "Vybrané", "Výběr") instead of "Označit" ("Označit vše", "Označené", "Označené"), which is a better alternative in most context and has been used in Czech Mac OS localization in the past (probably since System 6.0).

Discussion:

"Vybrat" means to pick one or a small number of elements, it would be used is used as a natural translation of "Choose" or "Pick" in most context. It can be used to mean "to select an arbitrary area" (as opposed to one of a few predefined areas). "Vybrat vše" as a translation for "Select All" also sounds very unnatural (similar to "Choose all" in English) and suggest the other common meaning of the word "vybrat": to withdraw or scoop out.

"Označit" covers all the meanings in which Select is used in Mac software and can be more naturally used in the context "Select an area" ("Označit oblast"), "Select all", ("Označit vše"). The only possible drawback is that "Označit" can be used to mean "to mark". This should not be an issue, as various more specific translation of the word "Mark" can be used when needed. (Mail already uses "Vložit značku". Alternatives include "Vložit/Přidat značku/označení". In context where "Mark as ..." needs to be used "Označit jako ..." can also be used without ambiguity.).

Additionally, "Označit" has been used for "Select" since classic Mac OS and Czech Mac users are used to it.
result.title: Confusing translation of "Select" in Czech localization

result.description:
This is a feature request to disclose the fact that a NSobject dragged from the Object Library and with it's class changed to another object that is available in the Object Library is different from dragging a instance of that type from the Object Library.

For example dragging a NSObject and changing it to a NSDrawer, states in the display : "Custom Class, Class NSDrawer" the same as dragging a second NSDrawer from the library.

The underlying structure in the xib file discloses that the first one is actually a NSCustomObject, while only the second one is a NSDrawer, and this can cause major problems in the specific case of NSDrawer for example as illustrated in my test project.

The first object is described as :

<object class="NSCustomObject" id="999004482">
	<string key="NSClassName">NSDrawer</string>
</object>

the second one as:

<object class="NSDrawer" id="586887452">
	<nil key="NSNextResponder"/>
	<string key="NSContentSize">{100, 100}</string>
	<string key="NSMinContentSize">{0, 0}</string>
	<string key="NSMaxContentSize">{10000, 10000}</string>
	<int key="NSPreferredEdge">2</int>
	<double key="NSLeadingOffset">0.0</double>
	<double key="NSTrailingOffset">15</double>
	<nil key="NSParentWindow"/>
	<nil key="NSDelegate"/>
</object>

Aside from the missing attributes in the inspector pane for the first one it is indistinguishable from the second one in the interface.

Notes:

Additionally if a custom object's class is changed into a class that exists in the Object Library it could be effectively transformed into that altogether instead of remaining a NSCustomObject with a class that is not custom.

09-May-2011 11:40 AM Tariq Zaid:
Summary:

Using an iPad 2 with the Smart Cover closed.  Device is locked.

When your application is in the foreground (with cover closed) and you receive a local notification, the notification is launched properly (you hear the notification).  When you open the cover, the notification will be displayed with your application in the background.  If you press the action button on your notification, no UIApplicationDelegate callback is invoked.  You do NOT receive any notice of a button being pressed (as you do not differentiate between the Close button and the Action button).  As a result, if your application attempts to react to the action button, it's impossible.

For example: VoIP application trying to accept a phone call.  When receiving a phone call, the user opens the smart cover and sees the notification.  The user presses 'Answer' but the application receives no notification of Close/Answer and is forced to display another dialog of sorts to prompt the user to accept the call.

Steps to Reproduce:

1- Lock application using Smart Cover
2- Receive a Local Notification
3- Unlock application using Smart Cover
4- You will see a notification (Expected)
5- You press answer - No callbacks are called (Unexpected)

Expected Results:
Some callback on the UIApplicationDelegate that will tell us whether or not a local notification has been accepted.

Actual Results:
No callback, application must display a second prompt -- this is poor user experience.

Regression:
Unknown, but most likely not a regression.

Notes:

From the documentation: "When the system delivers a local notification, several things can happen, depending on the application state and the type of notification. If the application is not frontmost and visible, the system displays the alert message, badges the application, and plays a sound—whatever is specified in the notification. If the notification is an alert and the user taps the action button (or, if the device is locked, drags open the action slider), the application is launched. In the application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions: method the application delegate can obtain the UILocalNotification object from the passed-in options dictionary by using the UIApplicationLaunchOptionsLocalNotificationKey key. The delegate can inspect the properties of the notification and, if the notification includes custom data in its userInfo dictionary, it can access that data and process it accordingly. On the other hand, if the local notification only badges the application icon, and the user in response launches the application, the application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions: method is invoked, but no UILocalNotification object is included in the options dictionary.

If the application is foremost and visible when the system delivers the notification, no alert is shown, no icon is badged, and no sound is played. However, the application:didReceiveLocalNotification: is called if the application delegate implements it. The UILocalNotification instance is passed into this method, and the delegate can check its properties or access any custom data from the userInfo dictionary.
result.title: The iPad 2 Smart Cover breaks Push/Local Notification Handling in Foreground

result.description:
Summary:
With iOS4, developers can choose to update the application icon badge by scheduling a UILocalNotification and setting its property applicationIconBadgeNumber.

According to the Discussion section of the documentation:
"The default value is 0, which means "no change.” The application should use this property’s value to increment the current icon badge number, if any."

This seem to suggest that applicationIconBadgeNumber can at least add on to any existing value on the icon badge, if any. However this is not so.

The applicationIconBadgeNumber, when set to any number, will override any existing badge number without regard for existing value.

So a developer cannot set applicationIconBadgeNumber of an UILocalNotification to 1 and expect iOS to increment the existing badge count by 1.

Steps to Reproduce:
N/A

Expected Results:
N/A

Actual Results:
N/A

Regression:
N/A

Notes:
Developers resort to scheduling a duplicate set of UILocalNotification with no alertBody and soundName just to update the badge icon without wiping out any existing value on the badges.

The first problem that this causes is that it uses up twice as many local notifications, which already has a maximum limit of 64.

The second problem is that this requires developers to maintain their own count internally so that they can update the badges with the absolute number to be shown on the icon.

The workaround is counter-intuitive when iOS could have just increment or even decrement the badge icon by the applicationIconBadgeNumber property.

This should have been the correct behaviour according to the write up in the documentation anyway, so I have reason to believe that this implementation is buggy and should be resolved.
result.title: applicationIconBadgeNumber in UILocalNotification doesn't work like it should

result.description:
The clock() function is documented in its man page as follows:

"The clock() function determines the amount of processor time used since the invocation of the calling process, measured in CLOCKS_PER_SECs of a second."

In a "Standards" note, it says:

"The clock() function conforms to ISO/IEC 9899:1990 (``ISO C90'').  However, Version 2 of the Single UNIX Specification (``SUSv2'') requires CLOCKS_PER_SEC to be defined as one million.  FreeBSD does not conform to this requirement; changing the value would introduce binary incompatibility and one million is still inadequate on modern processors."

Mac OS X does in fact set CLOCKS_PER_SEC to one million, making clock() useless for actually timing anything. The man page implies (albeit weakly) that OS X follows the FreeBSD convention, not the SUSv2.

The man page should be updated to make this limitation clearer (that clock() time can't be translated to seconds), and possibly suggest an alternative way of measuring elapsed time that is still monotonic.
result.title: Documentation for CLOCKS_PER_SEC does not match behavior
Static analyzer should catch calls to dealloc

result.description:
Summary:
On some wifi networks, the iPhone stops receiving ARP responses after a set of procedures. This breaks establishment of connections between hosts on the local subnet with an EHOSTDOWN error.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Put a Mac and an iPhone on the same wifi network
2. Confirm that the Mac can ping and otherwise connect to the iPhone
3. Lock the iPhone's screen and wait for the wifi to time out and disconnect.
4. Unlock and let iPhone reconnect to the wifi

Expected Results:
4. Ping and other local subnet communication works fine

Actual Results:
4. Ping fails with "host is down", connect() fails with EHOSTDOWN

Notes:
It appears that gratuitous ARPs correctly update the device's ARP cache, but that ARP responses to queries sent by the device are sometimes ignored by the device. 

This is only reproducible on a few wifi networks and even then, only sometimes.

The reason why we suspect the OS rather than the network is because the way we encountered this problem: our iPhone app connects to our Mac app with TCP, but only after receiving an UDP broadcast announcing the Mac app's existence on the network. Since we're receiving the UDP packet, there is obviously some sort of connection between the Mac and iOS app.

We have encountered the problem on several devices; we jailbroke one of them to capture network logs with tcpdump, and did testing with ping and Safari (to apache on the Mac) to confirm that the problem was not in our app (since ping and Safari exhibited the same problem).

Using tcpdump we thought we found that the iPhone did not receive the ARP response from the Mac, even though we clearly saw the response going out from the Mac in Wireshark.

Taking the Mac's wifi down and up again seems to temporarily fix the problem; perhaps because of the gratuitous ARP that is sent when this happens.

Alternative steps to reproduce:
1. Mac joins wifi
2. iPhone joins wifi
3. iPhone lists `arp -an`:
? (192.168.1.1) at 0:9:f:d0:86:51 on en0 [ethernet]
4. Mac pings  iPhone.
5. Mac successfully looks up IP for iPhone with ARP.
6. iPhone receives ping. iPhone tries to look up Mac with ARP; fails.
7. iPhone lists `arp -an`:
? (192.168.1.1) at 0:9:f:d0:86:51 on en0 [ethernet]
? (192.168.1.84) at (incomplete) on en0 [ethernet]
8. Mac shows "Request timeout for icmp_seq [n]"
result.title: ARP responses not getting through after wifi powerdown

result.description:
It would be nice if IOSurface on Mac OS X was an public, documented API. Right now, it is a framework that is merely mentioned in some places in the official documentation (see links below). However, there is no separate document describing the internals or usage of the framework.
This technology is very interesting for high-performance realtime applications that use inter-process communication and have to deal with textures on the graphics card. Therefore, detailed information on how texture sharing works, performance considerations, recommended design patterns (maybe including a recommended way of IPC), limits imposed by hardware, graphics card drivers or other software etc. would be very helpful.


Official documentation referencing IOSurface:

1) CVPixelBuffer Reference:
http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/QuartzCore/Reference/CVPixelBufferRef/Reference/reference.html

2) Technical Note TN2267: Video Decode Acceleration Framework Reference:
http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#technotes/tn2267/_index.html

3) Mac OS X Technology Overview: Mac OS X Frameworks:
http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/MacOSX/Conceptual/OSX_Technology_Overview/SystemFrameworks/SystemFrameworks.html
result.title: IOSurface as public, documented API on Mac OS X

Summary:  iOS is pretty good at autodetecting phone number strings and hyperlinking them to allow instantaneous dialing.  But the calendar app has a bug that prevents dialing phone numbers that include the "#" symbol.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a calendar event with the following details:

    Title: Weekly Conference Call to Discuss Sales
    Time: Friday July 6 2007 13:00-13:30
    Location: Banff conference room 
    Notes:  concall: 622-555-1212,,453452# url: http://www.foo.com 

2. save the event
3. view the Event Details for this calendar item
4. note that the ENTIRE concall phone number ("622-555-1212,,453452#") is a hyperlink
5. tap the hyperlinked concall number
6. you will be prompted with a "Cancel / Call" dialog box - tap the "Call" button
7. nothing happens (i.e., no phone call)

Expected Results:
the phone should dial the "622-555-1212,,453452#" number

Actual Results:
the phone does not dial the number.

Regression:
this has never worked.  (NOTE this problem does not occur with my coworker's BlackBerry...)

Notes:

As an enterprise user, I have a calendar that is FULL of this phone number format, since the "#" is frequently used to interact with conference calls or voicemail systems.  The only way to dial them is to carefully copy the number, switch to the iPhone app, paste in the new number, delete the # and then dial.


note that this problem with the pound sign seems to be specific to the calendar app.

i.e., if you launch notes.app and add "622-555-1212,,232323#" the resulting hyperlink WILL dial properly.


Update: 23-May-2011 I was notified that this is a duplicate of apple bug #9367037
result.title: the calendar app won't allow dialing a phone number that includes a pound sign

* Check out a new copy, which we'll call A. A has the auto-generated default scheme.

* Add a shared scheme to your working copy, which we'll call "Adhoc". Commit it.

* Update A's working copy, which now reflects both A's default scheme and the Adhoc scheme. [A is happy.]

* Now check out another new copy, call it B. B has only the Adhoc scheme. Pressing the Autogenerate button does nothing. [B is unhappy.]

* Commit your original shared scheme to version control. 

* Update B's working copy. B now has the default and Adhoc schemes. [B is happy.]

* Update A's working copy. A now has three schemes, and gets confused until they're instructed to delete their un-shared scheme. [A is unhappy.]

Expected Results: Adding a shared scheme should not affect the presence or absence of the default, autogenerated scheme.

Actual Results: Adding a shared scheme throws current and future users of the Xcode project into disequilibrium. Either the new users must import a new scheme, or existing users must delete their original scheme.
result.title: Sharing an Xcode 4 scheme breaks default autogeneration

result.description:
Summary:
The Unicode code points U+2308 to U+230B represent the mathematical notation for the ceiling and floor functions: ⌈x⌉ and ⌊x⌋.

Their correct rendition can be seen in, for example, TeX renderings on the Wikipedia page http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_and_ceiling_functions . There is also a helpful note in the Unicode Standard (http://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U2300.pdf): “These characters are tall and narrow mathematical delimiters, in contrast to the quine corners or half brackets. They are also distinct from CJK corner brackets, which are wide quotation marks.”

However, several Mac OS X system fonts have incorrect glyphs for these code points; they are similar to the heavy box drawing corner glyphs U+250F U+2513, U+2517 and U+251B (┏, ┓, ┗, ┛). Most significantly, this includes Heiti SC Light, which (for some unfathomable reason) is used as the fallback font for these glyphs. This means that random text using these symbols – such as the aforementioned Wikipedia page – look wrong.

The complete list of affected system fonts is:
Heiti SC Light
Heiti SC Medium
Heiti TC Light
STFangSong Regular
STHeiti Light
STHeiti Regular
STKaiti Regular
STSong Regular

Apple Symbols Regular has a different error with these glyphs: they are too low, being limited to about x-height.

Menlo Regular has correct floor and ceiling glyphs.


Steps to Reproduce:
On a Mac without exotic fonts installed, copy this bug report into TextEdit and set the font to Helvetica.

Expected Results:
The first sentence should contain the letter x with ceiling and floor brackets. (Changing the font to Menlo achieves this.)

Actual Results:
The first sentence contains the letter x waving its arms up and down.

Regression:
Unknown; not tested on earlier systems.
result.title: Faulty system fonts (floor and ceiling operators)

Summary:

We serve podcasts+media from a cluster of Xserves.  Since iTunes 10.2.2 shipped, we've noticed servers dropping offline periodically.  We've correlated this to iTunes clients refreshing podcast feeds.  It seems that iTunes is hitting every item in the feed, multiple times, simultaneously.  I've occasionally been able to get iTunes to do this by subscribing to a podcast, quitting, and then relaunching iTunes.  All of the "Bad" traffic has an AppleCoreMedia user agent, while all of the "Good" traffic (the connections actually performing the downloads seen in the iTunes UI) have an iTunes user agent.

I've attached an excerpt of an apache log showing the type of traffic being generated by a single student launching iTunes.  Since all of these loads involve a database call and pull files off Xsan, you can imagine how a few students doing this can essentially trash a server - it causes the 10.5.8 network stack to hang for 5+ minutes.

Steps to Reproduce:

Difficult to reproduce consistently.  As mentioned above, I've had the best luck subscribing to a feed, then quitting mid-download, then relaunching iTunes.  I've also noticed that just clicking on undownloaded podcast items in iTunes generates a fair number of requests to the server, though just for the file that's being highlighted, not for every item in the feed.

Expected Results:
Files loaded

Actual Results:
Busted server


Regression:
It *appears* to have started since the release of 10.2.2.


Notes:
result.title: iTunes podcast subscription performs denial of service

-----------------------------------
Summary:
-----------------------------------

Many PDF files generated via Quartz on machines running OS X 10.6.7 result in errors, hangs or crashes when opened by PDF readers from other vendors.

The problematic PDF files are:

- generated using -[NSView dataWithPDFInsideRect:];
- generated on a machine running OS X 10.6.7;
- generated from a view hierarchy which includes a non-empty NSTextView (ie, text is included).

We have been unable to concretely determine if a particular type of font is problematic. Certain fonts seem to cause more problems than others, generally OpenType Postscript fonts. We have seen this issue with the following fonts:

- Ancron
- DIN-Light
- GaramondPremrPro
- GiddyupStd
- Lithos Pro Regular
- Minion Pro
- Myriad Pro
- Tekton-Pro
- TravelingTypewriter
- Trajan Pro

Opening these PDF files with software provided by other vendors or on other platforms results in errors, crashes, or hangs. We have seen this using:

- Adobe Acrobat Reader ("Cannot extract the embedded font...")
- Harlequin RIP ("ERROR=syntaxerror" or "invalid font")
- HP RIP
- Xeikon RIP


-----------------------------------
Steps to Reproduce:
-----------------------------------

- Launch /Applications/TextEdit on a Mac running 10.6.7.
- Type the text "this is a test".
- Choose Edit -> Select All.
- Change the font to Minion Pro Regular.
- Print and choose to save to a PDF rather than printing.

-----------------------------------

A fully compliant PDF file that can be rendered on any platform. 


-----------------------------------
Actual Results:
-----------------------------------

A non-compliant PDF file that causes hangs and/or errors when rendered on non-Apple platforms.


-----------------------------------
Regression:
-----------------------------------

Downgrading the operating system to 10.6.6 results in a fully compliant PDF file that behaves as expected.


-----------------------------------
Notes:
-----------------------------------

There is much discussion about this issue online. Some examples:

http://db.tidbits.com/article/12078
http://discussions.apple.com/thread.jspa?threadID=2792142

On recent 13" MacBook Pro models that have only the integrated Intel HD 3000 GPU, a certain sequence of OpenGL calls involving multisampling and glPushAttrib causes a black screen.

The window shows two green rectangles.


Actual results:

One of the rectangles is black.

I have reproduced the bug on both Mac OS X 10.6.7 (10J3250), and 10.7 (11A419).

In the source code, the key lines are glEnable(GL_MULTISAMPLE), glPushAttrib, glPopAttrib, and glDisable(GL_MULTISAMPLE).  If you comment out glPushAttrib and glPopAttrib, or either the glEnable or glDisable, the bug goes away.  It doesn't seem to matter which attribute mask you pass to glPushAttrib.

result.description:
Summary:

Local and remote (push) notifications on iOS are improperly handled by the OS when they are received during a sync operation.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Unlock the iOS device.
(1.5. Optionally launch an application.)
2. Initiate a sync via iTunes.
3. Cause a local or remote notification to be delivered during the sync.
4. Observe the system launching the application that registered to receive the notification.

Expected Results:

The springboard or active application would be returned focus after the sync operation completed.
When the notification is received by the application already running, the notification should not be passed to the application.

Actual Results:

The application that registered to receive the notification that was triggered is launched. If it was already the currently active application, the notification is passed to the application and the active view potentially changes from where it was left by the user before the sync began.

Regression:

N/A

Notes:

I did not test on any devices or OS version aside from iPhone 4/4.3.1, but I did test all permutations of this bug: Local (with and without active application), and remote (with and without active application)

This is only a major problem for applications that cause a destructive action to be initiated automatically when launched in response to receiving a notification. For example, an application might automatically deactivate a timer interface if launched in response to a local notification being triggered. Normally that automatic action would only happen if the user tapped “View” on an alert dialog, or swiped to unlock and view the notification from the lock screen.

It appears that the completion of a sync operation when the device is already unlocked triggers the same code path that is triggered when the user performs that swipe, which does not provide the desired result.

This bug does not manifest if the device is locked when a sync is initiated.
result.title: Notifications are improperly handled by iOS after a sync operation completes

result.description:
100 UDIDs per year has always been a bit frustrating, but it has become a major problem since the iPad was introduced. Most of my beta testers have 2 or even 3 devices now, and the majority of them upgrade every year. I also have a sizable collection of my own devices I use. And of course, sometimes a device has problems which usually means it gets replaced. This results in a fairly small number of beta testers total.

I imagine this is less of a problem at a larger company where you might have a large number of dedicated beta testers, where you're getting more out of each one. For an indie company that's just not possible. Most of my testers are volunteers. They don't always have time to test thoroughly. Over time they may lose interest in testing and I have to get someone else to replace them. Or I may have someone whose help I need with a particular issue but can't devote the time to test long term. Any time this happens I lose valuable slots for most of the year.

Yet another problem I'm dealing with right now is multiple apps. When your testers are volunteers they're not necessarily going to want to test all of your apps.

I've suggested in the past that it would work out a lot better for developers if we were authorizing iTunes accounts, rather than devices. A yearly limit on iTunes accounts would be much less of an issue. Perhaps a higher limit could also still be placed on UDIDs, to ensure no one's abusing the system—and it would be in developer's own interests to weed out testers trying to do this.

Another possibility might be to reward long time developers. Increase our limit every year, perhaps. (You could require a certain minimum of app sales to get the increase.) If a developer has been making money off the App Store for a while, surely he's much less likely to abuse the system, because he has far more to lose if his account is shut down.

result.description:
Summary:
In browsers that correctly implement the Core Animation drawing model NPAPI spec (Chrome, Firefox), the QuickTime plugin leaks a QTMovieLayer (and other associated objects, like QTMovieLayerPrivate) every time the plugin is instantiated in CA mode.

Steps to Reproduce:
1) Open Chrome on 10.6
2) Go to a page with a non-transparent QT plugin; e.g.:
    http://trailers.apple.com/trailers/independent/thegirlonthetrain/
3) Repeatedly open and close the trailer popup while running under Instruments

Expected Results:
No leaks

Actual Results:
A QTMovieLayer is leaked every time the popup is closed.

Notes:
The issue is almost certainly that QuickTime implements the memory model that Safari implemented for the CA drawing model prior to the spec actually being accepted into NPAPI. As part of the spec process, the memory semantics of the returned CALayer changed. According to the spec, the QuickTime plugin is responsible for balancing its own retain and release counts on the Layer it vends.
See https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=58282 for discussion.
result.title: QuickTime plugin leaks QTMovieLayers in browsers with correct CA implementations

Summary: SyncHandwritingHotKey() disables the Chinese Handwriting hotkey if any UI process is sandboxed.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run a UI program in a sandbox that denies at least these 2 things:

(deny file-read-data
       (subpath "/System/Library/Caches")  ; required
       )

(deny mach-lookup
       (global-name "com.apple.pasteboard.1")  ;required
       )

Running Google Chrome 11 or older works for example.

2. Enable the Chinese Handwriting IME by adding Chinese to the enabled input methods in sysprefs

3. Try to toggle the IME with ctrl-shift-space

Expected Results:
Should work.

Actual Results:
Does not work. The reason for this is that HIToolbox's SyncHandwritingHotKey() does something along these lines:

  CFTypeRef[] keys = { kTISPropertyBundleID };
  CFTypeRef[] values = { CFSTR("com.apple.inputmethod.ChineseHandwriting") };
  CFDictionaryRef dict
    = CFDictionaryCreate(kCFAllocatorDefault, keys, values, 1,
                         &kCFTypeDictionaryKeyCallBacks,
                         &kCFTypeDictionaryValueCallBacks);

  CFArrayRef arr = TISCreateInputSourceList(dict, /*ignorefilter=*/false);
  int count = CFArrayGetCount(arr);
  CFRelease(dict);
  CFRelease(arr);
  if (!count)
    CGSRemoveHotKey(...)

In a sandboxed process, TISCreateInputSourceList() will fail to load the IME bundle due to lack of file access, and then the function will globally uninstall the hotkey. A possible fix would be to only uninstall the hotkey if stat()ing /System/Library does _not_ fail (to check for being sandboxed), or to just never remove this hotkey once it's been installed.

Regression:
No.
Notes:


See http://crbug.com/31225 for more analysis.
result.title: SyncHandwritingHotKey() disables the Chinese Handwriting hotkey if any UI proces

06-Apr-2011 10:26 AM Dair Grant:
Summary:
Several math.h functions (isnormal, isfinite, isinf, isnan, signbit) are implemented as inlines on arm, and as either inlines or real functions on x86 depending on the -ffast-math flag (the x86 version of math.h declares them as inlines by default, but as external functions when -ffast-math is enabled).

The Simulator traps calls to these functions and calls abort(), presumably to ensure code doesn't make any reference to them.

However since the Simulator is running x86 code, if that code is compiled with -ffast-math then these symbols should be allowed (since they are present in the x86 libSystem, and they will always be inlined on arm).


Steps to Reproduce:
Create a new iPhone project, add a reference to isnan(42) in didFinishLaunchingWithOptions.


Expected Results:
The project should compile and run in the Simulator.


Actual Results:
If the project does not use -ffast-math, the Simulator will execute it correctly.

If -ffast-math is added as a compiler option, the Simulator will kill the app on the call to isnan() with:

---------------------------------
Detected an attempt to call a symbol in system libraries that is not present on the iPhone:
__isnand called from function -[FastMathAppDelegate application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:] in image FastMath.
If you are encountering this problem running a simulator binary within gdb, make sure you 'set start-with-shell off' first.
---------------------------------


Regression:
This validation didn't happen prior to 3.2.6 (it may have been added earlier, but I think I was using 3.2.4 before and it didn't happen).


------------------

Closed by Apple as duplicate of rdar://8158484.
result.title: Xcode 3.2.6 Simulator incompatible with -ffast-math

05-Apr-2011 04:18 PM Marc Hoyois:
Summary:
The bug happens when attaching a listener to the 'message' event on the 'safari.self' object of an 'about:blank' document created by Safari just before the loading of an iframe's actual document. Sometimes the listener will be copied to the latter document (which also has its own), causing this document to handle every message from the global page twice. NB: I do mean the same document, not the same tab.

Steps to Reproduce:
1) Install the 'test' extension. Here's how the extension works:
For every document in the page that loads an external resource, the extension's injected script assigns a unique ID to the document and sends a message to the global page; the global page then sends a message back. The injected script and the global page show an alert box before sending their messages and the injected script does so again upon receiving the answer, each showing the document's unique ID.

2) Now navigate to:
http://www.glogger.mobi/userpub2.php?username=guest&i=2009_04_26_21_09_58_75441700

Expected Results:
Theoretically, on any webpage, this extension will produce a number of matching triples of alert boxes: 'Sending message from document i', 'Sending answer to document i', and 'Answer received by document i'.
This happens correctly with the 'test-fix' extension that uses a workaround (see note 1 below).

Actual Results:
On the above webpage, document 1 gives two notifications of reception of answer, even though the answer was sent once from the global page: the handler of the 'message' event is run twice.

Notes:
1) An easy workaroud is to not register the listener to the message event if window.location.href is 'about:blank'. That's what the test-fix extension does and it shows the source of the bug.
2) This hasn't anything to do with the 'beforeload' event, I'm just using it as a convenient way to assign unique IDs to document, making the demonstration clearer. But using a simpler injected script that sends its message after a setTimeout (long enough for the tab to load completely and the about:blank pages to disappear) and alerts on every message sent and received and doing the math, the number of alerts upon reception is still more than it should be, i.e. it is

(# of documents in the tab) * (# of documents in the tab + # of documents with duplicate listeners).

This is what the test2 extension demonstrates (in the above web page there are 4 documents whence 20 answers received instead of the expected 16).
3) I'm not sure if the creation of all these about:blank documents is necessary, but I guess not since it happens far less often in the latest WebKit builds. If it is not necessary then it shouldn't happen.
4) There should be a way to prevent an extension's scripts to run on about:blank pages. The internal whitelist does not allow it. I can imagine that an extension would want to inject scripts there, for example to build a default blank page, but for most extensions there would be no point. Currently these about:blank pages multiply roughly by two the amount of Javascript being interpreted!
5) It took me a whole day to narrow this one down and produce those minimal extensions, so please give this some serious consideration :) I think that it's a pretty huge bug given note 4, and the fact that it can produce baffling results that will be very hard for a developer to debug (case in point).

result.description:
Blocks (as in, closures) are created on the stack and these stack blocks are implicitly destroyed when they go out of scope. However, in reality, the memory is often left undisturbed and this makes it extremely easy to accidentally use these blocks after the point where it becomes illegal to do so.

I propose that a compiler option be added that explicitly destroys stack-allocated blocks after they go out of scope by writing over their isa and implementation pointers. This would cause a small speed hit in exchange for catching all such misuses of blocks.

I believe the isa pointer should be overwritten with some sort of small proxy class that reports all accesses, like NSZombie. Perhaps even simply reusing NSZombie for this purpose would be sufficient. For the implementation pointer, a function with an informative name, like CRASHED_BECAUSE_CODE_CALLED_A_STACK_BLOCK_THAT_HAS_GONE_OUT_OF_SCOPE which simply abort()s would be really helpful.

This should be optional because it will add a small speed hit, and could also break nonconforming code that happens to be working at the moment.
result.title: Wipe out stack blocks when they go out of scope

result.description:
Summary:

Background:
Mac OSX Server 10.6.7 serving AFP group folders, and serving a Time Machine backup location. Clients are a mixture of 10.6.7 and 10.5.8.

Most users have network home folders, but a few have portable home directories, and a few have laptops. Many more users than actual workstations ("hot bunking" so to speak).

As the Admin, I have a local admin account on each workstation. User accounts don't have admin priveledges.

My local admin userID and credentials are NOT the same as the admin account ID and credentials on the server (to prevent the compromise of a single workstation from getting admin control over the server.) And my server credentials are NOT stored in the local client keychain.

Using Workgroup Manager, I am pushing Time Machine settings to each client. The settings I am pushing are consistent with those examples in the Apple Manuals (specify URL of the time machine backup destination, but not username). The exact info I'm pushing is as follows "afp://server4.local/timemachine3".  (The server is on a private network and not publically-accessible, so no fancy FQDN is being used, and doesn't appear to be related to my issue.)  These Workgroup Manager settings worked in getting each Client Machine to start backing up to the server destination as specified and expected.

We have strict password policies (controlled thru Workgroup Manager) that require changing passwords periodically. The users are doing this as expected.

The Problem:
When the first Time Machine backup ran for each client workstation, it used the username and password of whichever user was logged in at that time to establish the credentials for that TM backup. On the server, I see those users as the owners of the TM backup sparseimages associated with each client machine.

On the clients, (using my local admin priveledges) I see an entry in the "System" keychain with that users's password that was in effect on the day the TM backup was first created.  TM backups continue as expected without incident.

Once the user changes their password (per the periodic password change policy), the TM password stored in the System keychain DOESN'T update. All TM backups from that day forward fail due to the password mismatch.

I can manually correct this, one machine at a time, by manually updating the TM password that is stored in the "System" Keychain using my local Admin credentials, but that is not an optimal solution (by far).

I have also tried creating the TM backup using my SERVER admin credentials, but this hasn't worked reliably for me in the past either (I'm not sure why, but I suspect it is due to AFP not working right when more than one userID is connecting to the server from the same client), and also leaves my server admin credentials on all the client machines (some of which are laptops and travel a lot), which is a security risk I am not willing to take.

The Apple Server manuals seem to suggest that backing up to a server offering Time Machine backups should "just work" without all this hassle, including backing up all local client files, regardless of who is logged in, and how the authentication is made. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Push TM destination/policy to client workstations thru workgroup manager.
2. User logs into client workstation.  First Time Machine backup runs.  A Keychain item is silently added to the "System" keychain for that workstation, with the logged-in user's current password.
3. Sometime later, the user changes their login password, thru normal means.
4. Time Machine backups fail from this point forward, due to outdated password still being stored in the "System" Keychain.



Expected Results:
IMHO, Time Machine should generate and use a certificate for authentication between client and server, not the password of whichever user just happened to be logged in at the moment the first TM backup was run.

Also, storing the currently logged-in user's login password in the "System" Keychain when the first TM backup is kicked-off seems like a security flaw.  Suppose I'm the admin of the mac, but my user has "priveledged" information that they want to keep private, perhaps by using FileVault to protect their home folder.  

As the admin, I can compromise their FileVault information by seeing that their password was stored in the "System" Keychain under an item called Time Machine.

Actual Results:
TM not working after user changes password.
User's password exposed to admin, by being stored in the "System" Keychain, where the admin can view it.


Regression:

Notes:
I'm filing this as a "Serious Bug" because it prevents Time Machine from reliably backing up multiple workstations to a OSX Server, if a periodic password change policy is used.
I also think this should be considered for a "Security Flaw" since it is possible for someone who might be a network admin to expose individual's login password, and thus unlock their FileVaults.
result.title: Time Machine backup to OSX Server fails after user changes their login password

result.description:
Summary:

I propose an addition to the Apple Push Notification Service (APNS) whereby the APNS provider can supply a payload data in the notification that receiving iOS devices can fetch and make available to the notified app on launch. This would shorten the initial usage pattern of a client app to: open the app, parse the pre-cached block of update data, use the app. The delay of logging in, making the request for updated data and resulting download is removed. 

Implementation:

The notification provider (app or data vendor) would send the payload to APNS with the notification but only the notification, not the payload, would be pushed to the iOS device by APNS. The notification sent to the iOS device would contain an APNS-provided URL where iOS itself can, if it chooses, download that payload and cache it ready for the app to use when it launches. This allows iOS to intelligently control when or if the available payload is downloaded and cached. 

Payloads would only ever be cached when the device is on standby to prevent any disruption to running apps. More intelligent decisions could be made such as only performing the pre-cache for regularly used apps, or caching based on the usage pattern of the app. Ultimately the goal is to have as current a set of data pre-cached as possible without sacrificing battery life or incurring excessive data charges.

Usage Case:

Take for example an app like Evernote which I use regularly for note taking. I'll often start a note on my iPhone when I think of something, then flesh it out on my iPad when I have time and finally I'll reference the article on my Mac when coding. Today when I use the app, I first have to wait for the initial sync of data to occur before I can edit that new note. With the pre-caching addition to APNS that I've proposed here, those updates would be waiting for the app to parse in the form of an NSData block that iOS had conveniently downloaded for me earlier when a push notification was received from Evernote to inform the device there was new notes available. 

Boxcar is another good example because the proposed pre-caching of update data would solve two problems with Boxcar: the initial sync delay and the fact that after I see a push notification from Boxcar, that notice is not immediately viewable in the app. If I receive a push notification from Boxcar to tell me of a new event, I naturally expect to see that event waiting for me in the list of notifications when I start the app. Instead, after seeing the push notification and starting the app I have to wait for Boxcar the app to catch up with the already received push notification. If that push notification also included a way for iOS to download the app-data payload for that, and other new, notifications then the updates would be ready and waiting for me when I started Boxcar after receiving the notification. 

API:

For developers the implementation would be simple: include a new key/value pair in the options dictionary that is given to the app in the existing appDidFinishLaunching:withOptions method. These new key/value pairs would allow the developer to access the latest pre-cached data block and state data such as when the block was downloaded, etc. The app then takes a look at the data, validates it and decides whether to parse and use the pre-cached payload or discard it. The point is that parsing this already-downloaded block of data is going to be much quicker than logging in and downloading updates when the app launches. Of course, a normal login and refresh would follow but at least the app is (more) ready to use when the user launches it to consume new data. 

More Information:

http://scotchandcode.com/2011/03/28/ios-push-notification-enhancement-pre-cached-update-payloads/
result.title: iOS Push Notification Enhancement: Pre-Cached Data Payloads

When exporting an iOS application using the organizer share functionality, and then choosing "Save for Enterprise Distribution" has a bug when creating the manifest plist file.

The metadata bundle-version key defines the software version of the to be installed application. Therefor it relates to the CFBundleVersion key in the apps info.plist. (http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#featuredarticles/FA_Wireless_Enterprise_App_Distribution/Introduction/Introduction.html%23//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009979)

- Select the archived application in the organizer
- Select the "Share" button
- Choose "iOS App Store Package (.ipa)"
- Select "Next"
- Activate the checkbox "Save for Enterprise Distribution"
- Fill out the Application URL field with any value, same for the title field
- Select "Save"

The manifest .plist file should have the bundle-version key present wit the value of CFBundleVersion from the apps info.plist

Actual Results:
The key and the value is completely missing.

Regression:
If the applications info.plist instead contains the CFBundleShortVersionString key, its value will be written to the manifest plist.

20-Mar-2011 12:37 PM Joel Bruner:
Finder Inherited ACL Duplication

Summary:
ACLs are redundantly duplicated in copy operations via Finder (but not cp -p in Terminal)

Steps to Reproduce:
On a fresh server install, nothing special, just AFP service running... 
1. Create a folder and make it an AFP share point (turn off Spotlight indexing for one less ACL in the mix)
2. Add a user to the folder ACL (a local, OD, or AD, doesn't matter), in this test case, Admin (501), the defaults permissions are fine (Read Only, Inheritance on)
3. Save and apply rights to folder
4. Create a test document  in TextEdit (on the server to eliminate OS X Client from the ACL equation) and save to folder created in step 1, you could also just touch a new filename too.
5. Duplicate the file in Finder, duplicate the duplicate, etc...
6. Examine the folder with ls -le, the original file will have no ACL, the duplicate will have ACLs applied, duplicates will start to have ACLs repeating/duplicating and "stacking up"
7. When the ACLs gets long enough (esp. on an app) Finder will crash when copying

Expected Results:
ACL methods are aware of an existing duplicate ACEs and do not append new ACEs to the ACL

Actual Results:
ACLs are duplicated and appended until Finder is unable to work with the file (Copy, get Info) without crashing

Regression:
10.6, 10.6.2, bug not present, results were consistent and as expected. 
Example permissions from the test file when duplicated in 10.6 or 10.6.2:
0: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

10.6.3 (and into 10.6.4) introduced the behavior of adding a Write ACE to the duplication of a file that only had a Read ACE on it, example output:

1st duplication (of file with no ACL):
0: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

2nd copy (of file above):
0: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
1: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

3rd, 4th copy, etc… did not duplicate past these two ACEs, why write rights were included is a mystery, it's as if the compliment from the Unix permissions were added because administrator is doing the copying on this file? Bizarre. 

Also Finder starts listing _3_ ACEs on a file that ls -le only lists with _2_, Finder saying this ghost ACE is "Custom".

10.6.5 introduced a new level of duplication, now not only was an errant Write ACE being added to a Read only ACE, but now those entries were being duplicated as well.
Example:
-rw-r--r--@ 1 administrator  admin  4 Mar 18 17:19 test copy 2.txt
 0: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 1: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 2: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

-rw-r--r--@ 1 administrator  admin  4 Mar 18 17:19 test copy 3.txt
 0: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 1: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 2: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 3: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 4: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

-rw-r--r--@ 1 administrator  admin  4 Mar 18 17:19 test copy 4.txt
 0: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 1: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 2: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 3: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 4: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 5: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 6: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

10.6.6 continued this behavior, which becomes fatal for Finder when copying/duplicating packages and Applicaion bundles in a folder with and ACL, Finder will become overwhelmed with the length of the ACL by the 3rd copy and fail, resulting in a truncated application or package and error -41. See the movie called "10.6.6 ACL Chess.app.mov", even one duplication in a folder with one ACL results in a file in the Chess.app have 12 ACEs!

10.6.6 does not address or change the duplication behavior introduced in 10.6.5, or the errant addition of Write rights to what should be a Read ACE introduced in 10.6.3

When "cp -p" is used to copy the errant ACEs are purged and properly reflect the ACL of the parent folder. Seems to be Finder's problem.

21-Mar-2011 11:47 AM Joel Bruner:
Further regression testing notes, AFP need not be involved, and client will behave the same as well when inheritance is turned on  (file_inherit,directory_inherit), just make the folder, apply an ACL with chmod, and Finder will duplicate ACEs without proper checking and duplicates will occur to the point of Finder error -41 on applications and packages.

While this bug affects both client and server, only server makes it easily possible by turning inheritance on by default when using the Server Admin AFP panel, whereas Finder does not turn on inheritance in it's ACLs that are added by Finder

Create a new folder in the root (to avoid any other possible ACL permissions, permission interactions), logged in as administrator (501) - you can also be logged in as anyone else who has write permissions to the folder.

Apply the folder ACLs (the same that server Server Manager would apply with inheritance on) using chmod:
1. mkdir ~/chmodACLTest
2. chmod +a "administrator allow list,search,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity,file_inherit,directory_inherit"  ~/chmodACLTest
3. Copy an application like Chess.app into the folder with Finder, duplicate/copy and recopy the copy, the 3rd duplicate will fail with Error -41 because ACLs are stacking up.
# for a simple file experiment
4. touch ~/chmodACLTest/test 
5. Go to Finder and duplicate the test file and its duplicates.
Inspect permissions in Finder and in addition to Read, the erroneous Write ACE is labeled Custom in Finder.

Inspect with Terminal:

$ ls -led ~/chmodACLTest
drwxr-xr-x+ 6 administrator  admin  204 Mar 21 10:29 chmodACLTest
 0: user:administrator allow list,search,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity,file_inherit,directory_inherit

$ ls -le

-rw-r--r--+ 1 administrator  admin  0 Mar 21 10:28 test

-rw-r--r--+ 1 administrator  admin  0 Mar 21 10:28 test copy

 1: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity

-rw-r--r--+ 1 administrator  admin  0 Mar 21 10:28 test copy 2

 1: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 2: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 3: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 4: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
-rw-r--r--+ 1 administrator  admin  0 Mar 21 10:28 test copy 3
 0: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 1: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 2: user:administrator inherited allow write,delete,append,writeattr,writeextattr,chown
 3: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 4: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 5: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 6: user:administrator inherited allow read,execute,readattr,readextattr,readsecurity
 7: user:_spotlight inherited allow read,execute

Notes on Admin's ACL being Read Only vs. Unix permissions:
You can also give admin write permissions in the ACL and the same behavior will occur, while it seems like a poor example to have the same user duplicating the file having Read Only in the ACL, it should and is possible, because the Unix permissions allow this, what the example highlights is that a Write ACE is inexplicably written when that is not supposed to be inherited from the parent folder.

result.description:
Summary:

After a 802.1X re-authentication, Mac OS X does DHCP Requests to the previous DHCP Server and waits 
one minute between attempts (doing a total of 3) before resorting back to a broadcasted DHCP Discove
r.

This poses problem if the VLAN assigned by the switch changed after the re-authentication. A Mac wil
l regain very slowly its network connectivity because it insists on doing the DHCP Requests where a 
DHCP Discover in the new VLAN would enable network connectivity in seconds.

Windows' behavior is it'll try 3 DHCP Requests in a row wait 2-3 seconds and if nothing came back fr
om the original server will issue broadcast a DHCP Discover.

The end result is that a Mac OS X machine will experience a loss of connectivity for 2-3 minutes whi
le for Windows its a mere Note: 0000005 seconds.

Steps to Reproduce:

- Connect a Mac OS X station on a wired switch using 802.1X for access authorization with RADIUS VLA
N assignment turned on
- Mac OS X client successfully authenticate gets VLAN A, obtains an IP
- We initiate a forced 802.1X re-authentication from the switch
- Mac OS X client successfully re-authenticate gets VLAN B
- Mac OS X client sends a DHCP Request on the server where it obtained it's last IP
- No such DHCP Server exists in this new VLAN so no one will reply
- After a couple of minutes the Mac OS X client abandon the DHCP Requests and will do a DHCP Discove
r

Expected Results:

If the DHCP Requests have no reply within a couple of seconds, the OS should do a DHCP Discover righ
t away to obtain an IP.

Actual Results:

It does 3 DHCP Requests and wait for one minute each for a reply leading to a 3 minutes of no networ
k connectivity even though it could work.

Regression:

10.5 and previous 10.6 are also affected but we made sure it was reproducible with 10.6.6

Notes:

A related problem existed for Wireless 802.1X and Wireless MAC Authentication in general but it has 
been fixed in 10.6.5.
result.title: Mac OS X doesn't renew DHCP after a 802.1x re-authentication on Ethernet

Summary:

When typing (at speed) on the iPad keyboard I sometimes miss a top-row key and the touch event is sent to the underlying content view. When this is something like a text view, such as when editing a document or text, the cursor is repositioned in the document. As a result the keystrokes that follow are entered into the document in the wrong place. This disruption hampers the use of the iPads keyboard for text editing. 

Suggestion:

Add a ~24px blank strip of keyboard between the top of the iPad's on-screen keyboard and the underlying content view. This content buffer would be dead space whereby a missed keystroke on a top-row key wouldnt result in a touch going to the underlying content view.

Summary:

Instruments provides an Automation instrument, which allows the developer to script UI actions using Javascript.  The command-line version of instruments allows the selection of the target app, of the instruments template, and the instrument itself, but has no way to pass the Javascript file containing the test actions itself to the underlying instrument.  So you can start up instruments, which starts up the app, with the right Automation instrument, does so in the context of the template, but has no way to receive instructions.

use instruments from the command-line with any iOS app, any template, and the automation instrument, with any timeout.
