result.description:
Summary:
The lack of trials on the Mac App Store severely limits the investment a customer is willing to make. If a customer sees an app that piques their interest, and can try it free for (say) 14 days, they’re far more likely to decide that it’s worth the money than if they only get to look at screenshots (or even movies) of it. There’s no better way for a customer to get a feel for the app than to use it, and likewise, there’s no better way for a developer to hook a customer than with a free trial which sells the polish of the app.

As a comparison, I have personally found that the iBooks samples to be the perfect hook. Once I’ve read the first few pages I’m far more likely to pay to read the rest. The same thing happens in a physical book store: I prefer buying physical books in a brick and mortar store (or online, if they have selected a good sample chapter) because I can leaf through and get some experience with the writing, whether it says something that intrigues me, whether it’s written in a way that I will want to continue reading. I think this is exactly analogous to the situation with apps in the Mac App Store.

I have long felt that this was a serious lack in the iOS App Store, but if anything it’s even more so in the Mac App Store due to the increased scope of the applications; increased development time and resources mean higher overheads, which means that a higher price is going to be required to be profitable. And of course profitable (without being _over_priced) apps are good for everyone: the users get good apps, developers get money—and so does Apple, both through the 30% cut and the increased investment by users in their Macs (and their next Mac, and the one after that, plus one for their parents and kids and …).

In addition, this would be an excellent opportunity for Apple to standardize some conventions with trials to avoid confusing a naïve userbase. For example, Apple could mandate user interface elements (perhaps even ones provided by Apple specifically for this purpose via new APIs) which state, clearly, how much longer is left in the trial. Apple-provided UI elements would also make it easy for the customer to buy the full version from within it. This could even occur outside the app’s address space to ensure that nothing can interfere with the transaction, in a manner similar to how the Dock can interact with an application externally to it.

If this proved successful—as I believe it will—it would then be a good starting point to introduce something similar on the iOS App Store, if desired.


Steps to Reproduce:
N/A

Expected Results:
N/A

Actual Results:
N/A

Regression:
N/A

Notes:
N/A
result.title: The benefit of time-limited Mac App Store trials

Summary:

The Mac App Store shows some apps as "Installed" even though they were not bought from the App Store. Due to this, app store users think it will 'pick up on' those apps and manage updates for them.

You know all this, but please see my "Notes" section before you close this as a dupe.

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Quit Mac App Store app if running
1. Download Transmit (by Panic, from their website)
2. Open Mac App Store
3. Find Transmit in Mac App Store
4. Note appearance of "price/free/buy/installed" (hereinafter "p/f/b/i") button next to Transmit in app store

Expected Results:

"p/f/b/i" button should show price, allowing users to buy the app.

Actual Results:

"p/f/b/i" button shows "Installed".

Regression:

Any Mac app that uses the same bundle identifier and version number for both a 'sideloaded' version as well as one available through the app store will exhibit this problem.

Notes:

- You want to be able to use the same bundle identifier as sideloaded versions of apps, e.g. so preferences migrate transparently, and apps that integrate with eachother by finding eachother through NSWorkspace don't have to special case different versions of these apps.
- You don't want the sideloaded app to show up in the Mac App Store as "Installed", developer blogs everywhere show evidence (in comments sections) that customers massively assume this means the app store will 'pick up on it'.
- Every app store app has a Receipt in it. If you add a check for that file just being present (no verification needed, as this is not about piracy but about the user experience well-intentioned users experience and the repercussions for developers if it stays broken like this) before showing the app as "Installed" everything would be better.

Suggested Criteria to validate that an app is installed:

1. App has same bundle identifier
2. App has a version number that has ever existed in the app store
3. App bundle contains a "_MASReceipt" folder in its "Contents" folder
result.title: Check for app store Receipt to determine "Installed" status

result.description:
06-Jan-2011 02:42 PM Daniel Jalkut:
Currently there is a conundrum for App Store developers who opted to choose unique bundle IDs for their Mac App Store apps, versus their traditional, self-sold Mac apps. For example, MarsEdit may now be present in two flavors on a particular user's Mac:

com.red-sweater.marsedit - Downloaded from red-sweater.com
com.red-sweater.macappstore - Downloaded from Mac App Store

The differing bundle IDs leads to a situation where the Mac App Store has no notion of the app already "existing" on the computer, and so encourages the customer to buy the app. Especially given the experience of the iOS App Store, where "Buying" an already-downloaded app is a safe, charge-free transaction, it seems like customers will be inclined to take this risk and repurchase even though they didn't want to.

A short term solution would be for the App Store app to recognize through some metadata on an app listing "equivalent" bundle IDs, the presence of which on the system should be considered conceptually the same as the app for sale, albeit not manageable using the Mac App Store's update facility.

In this way, the App Store app would look for either of the above bundle IDs on a user's Mac, and if present, would not display the "Buy" button.

Thanks,
Daniel
result.title: Provide means of App Store app identifying bundle IDs of "equivalent" apps

result.description:
06-Jan-2011 02:36 PM Daniel Jalkut:
A major customer confusion point stems from the fact that the App Store app identifies an application with matching bundle ID and version number as "installed" on the customer's Mac. My experience halfway through day one of fielding customer responses to this is they expect full integration with the Mac App Store features of updating, giving reviews, etc., based on this indication.

Clearly there are two classes of "installed" apps: those installed by Mac App Store, and which afford the customer all the privileges of being a MAS-purchasing owner of the software, and those installed by the user independently of the Mac App Store, which may share attributes with the MAS app such as name, version number, and bundle ID.

To reduce confusion please consider splitting the "installed" flag into two: "Installed" and "3rd Party Install" or something along those lines.

Thanks,
Daniel
result.title: Differentiate between MAS-installed and customer-installed apps

Summary:

We're running Mac OS X 10.6.5 Server for Open Directory Master, Mac OS X 10.6.4 Server for our AFP server, and Mac OS X 10.6.4 on clients bound to the OD Master. Workstations are bound to the OD Master for authentication & managed preferences (by user & group, none by machine) and users have mobile home folders.

We only white-list specific applications (by a single group) which users can run and generally do NOT sign them in Workgroup Manager as security doesn't need to be that tight (and it makes upgrades easier). However, a few applications (all stored in either /Applications or ~/Applications) are signed by the developer and users get the "You don't have permission to use the application" error when attempting to launch those applications. Applications which are NOT signed by the developer (and not signed in WGM) work correctly.

Putting the signed-by-the-developer application in a subdirectory and whitelisting that directory in WGM still does not allow the application to be run.

Steps to Reproduce:

1) Install an application which has been signed by the developer (in our case, we used FileMaker Pro 5.5 & Parallels Desktop 6) in /Applications on the client workstation.

2) Launch WGM and select a user or group which has application managed prefs.

3) Click the Preferences button in toolbar, select the Overview tab (it should be selected by default), then click the Applications icon.

4) Select the Applications tab (it should be selected by default) and ensure that the Always radio button is selected for Manage and the "Restrict which applications are allowed to launch" checkbox is checked (after all, this was supposed to be a user/group with managed applications).

result.description:
There is no nice (or is it even official?) way of detecting and handling the media keys on the user's keyboard. One can intercept events with type NSSystemDefined and subtype 8 in -[NSApplication sendEvents:], but this has major problem: any other applications that listen to the media keys will receive these events too. This means for example that if only Spotify is running and you want to pause your music, iTunes will start when you press play/pause. If you have VLC running in the background, it will also start playing.

Apple has solved this problem internally by having their media key using applications cooperate and resign media key controls to the application that was in the foreground most recently. However, there is no way for third party applications to join this cooperation. I request an API to expose media key nicely, together with an API to get exclusive usage of media keys, given that you were the latest application registered as such to be active.

I have implemented a workaround that does this using a CGEventTap at https://gist.github.com/764542. However, the class of events being captured is too broad and might cause problems with third party applications (we've already noticed Adobe Fireworks misbehaving when the tap is in place).
result.title: Exclusive lock on keyboard media keys

Summary:

IOCreatePlugInInterfaceForService creates a mach port and a CFMachPortRef to wrap it. IODestroyPlugInInterface appears to destroy the mach port somewhat before the CFMachPortRef. This causes a race condition where other code can allocate a mach port and then a CFMachPortRef that unexpectedly points to the existing (invalid) CFMachPortRef. This can cause the mach port to be unreliable which then has disastrous consequences on the code that uses it.


Steps to Reproduce:

Compile and run the attached program. Note that the vendor/product IDs are hardcoded in the _kVendorID and _kProductID constants. These IDs are for my Apple aluminum USB keyboard. You may need to change those to the IDs of some USB device on your system.

The attached program should run forever, spitting out "machport:" and "iterate:" logs.


Actual Results:

It runs briefly, then hits this assertion failure:

Assertion failed: (portctx.info == getctx.info), function TestMachPort, file usb-machport.c, line 94.

This indicates that an existing CFMachPortRef was found for the newly-allocated mach port, which should never happen.


Regression:

This was tested on a couple of different Macs with different USB devices and the problem was still present.

Removing the call to IODestroyPlugInInterface solves the problem, at the cost of leaking the IOKit plugin object each time.

N/A

result.description:
Summary:
On the command-line, it is impossible to set or remove ACL-entries on a symbolic link (symlink).
This can become a problem, if you have a directory with additional ACL-entries and apply the permissions of this directory to it's contents through the "Get Info"-panel: If there are symlinks within this directory, they are applied this ACL, which _cannot be removed_ through normal means later.

Steps to Reproduce:
0. Assume you are logged into the account "someuser" and there exists an account "someotheruser" as well
(In the shell:)
1. mkdir /tmp/acl_symlink_test && cd /tmp/acl_symlink_test
2. touch testfile && ln -s testfile link_to_file
3. chmod +a "someotheruser allow write" .
4. open /tmp
(In the Finder:)
5. select the "acl_symlink_test" folder and "Get Info"
6. authenticate as an admin-user and select the apply-to-all-subfolders-option from the gear-menu
(back in the shell:)
7. chmod -h -a# 0 /tmp/acl_symlink_test/link_to_file
8. ls -le /tmp/acl_symlink_test

Expected Results:
Step 8. outputs something like:
    total 8
    lrwxr-xr-x+ 1 someuser  wheel  8 26 Dez 18:12 link_to_file -> testfile
    -rw-r--r--  1 someuser  wheel  0 26 Dez 18:12 testfile
     0: user:someotheruser allow write
(I.e. the ACL is removed from the *symlink itself*.)

Actual Results:
Step 8. outputs something like:
    total 8
    lrwxr-xr-x+ 1 someuser  wheel  8 26 Dez 18:12 link_to_file -> testfile
     0: user:someotheruser allow write
    -rw-r--r--  1 someuser  wheel  0 26 Dez 18:12 testfile
(I.e. the "-h" option is ignored and instead of the symlink, the *link-target* is modified.)

Regression:
Unknown, but the age of [1] suggests, that it dates back to whichever version of 10.5 was current in early 2009.
Actually, it seems like the underlying issue is even older as the discussion [2] suggests (which dates back to 2008).

Notes:
According to [1] this is a known bug already filed under rdar://problem/6264303 some 20 months ago and marked as a duplicate of rdar://problem/5684438.
The author of [1] — back then — was kind enough to post a patch for chmod, which can be found under [3].

[1] http://0xced.blogspot.com/2009/03/chmod-acl-and-symbolic-links_23.html
[2] http://discussions.apple.com/thread.jspa?threadID=1440377&start=0&tstart=0
[3] http://pitaya.ch/radar/6264303/chmod.patch
result.title: /bin/chmod: Setting/Removing of ACL-Directives on Symbolic Links Unsuppoerted

result.description:
Problem Summary:
The Security API provides a very nice way for applications to store passwords in a secure way by having them written into keychains. The fact that only the application that has written a password to a keychain may later on access it (ACL restriction) is a great benefit in general, but it is a real pain if you want to develop applications that "work" on user's keychains, e.g. syncing passwords with some non OS X password services, transferring passwords between keychains, etc. In that case each access to the password of a password entry (or the private key of a private key entry) causes a dialog to be displayed. While these dialogs are a security feature in general, there are situations where they make useful software development impossible, since I cannot expect a user with 100+ items in a keychain to hit that dialog button 100+ times to allow an application to read all its password.

Solution:
The solution is as simple as adding two tiny features. First one is bulk operation. Instead of forcing the app to request permission for each item, the app can perform a bulk operation and the dialog will ask the user if the application in question may access 100+ items in the keychain (allowing the user to see a list of all items, if he really cares for it). This way the user once gives permission, not 100+ times. The second solution is even better and even more simple to integrate into the current code: A keychain has a *global ACL* with trusted applications. Trusted applications are allowed to bypass the ACLs for individual keychain items. If an application is in the global ACL, access is equal as if it was in the ACL of every existing keychain item. I know that this is somewhat risky, but adding an app to the global ACL doesn't have to be easy or user friendly. If it is necessary to perform complicated steps via keychain access, that would be acceptable, after all a user has to perform those steps only once in most cases. Just like item ACLs the hash of the application is verified, so when it changes, the system will ask the user again. A nice byproduct of the global ACL is that certain command line utilities can be added to that list, finally allowing certain keychain operations on headless systems that are currently really painful or impossible to implement.

This feature has been missed by developers for as long as keychain exists, so over a decade. Already 2006 people like Ken McLeod or Perry the Cynic have noted on the CDSA mailing list that those kind of features are really missing, e.g.

http://lists.apple.com/archives/apple-cdsa/2006/Aug/msg00013.html

and there are plenty of developers requesting them on that list over and over again, and still after so many years, nothing has happened, nothing has been improved. With the Internet always around and with services in the cloud, a locked up system like the current security API and keychains is just outdated. And if Apple is not dealing with that issue, I'm afraid that sooner or later some alternative API from some company like 1Password.com will be offered and all major applications will migrate to that API istead.

I know that you can write CDSA plugins, but those are not treated equally in all aspects and would not be transparent to all applications that use Sec* API calls. Further a storage plugin would not solve the problems, since an application still has to understand the internal "format" of a keychain file... in that case the app can as well directly operate on those files and bypass the security framework altogether.
result.title: Allow Bulk Operations on Keychains and Allow Trusted Helper Apps for Keychains

08-Dec-2010 10:47 AM Adrian Ward:
Summary:
It would save a lot of noodles and supporting infrastructure if Javascript patches within Quartz Composer documents supported composition-wide global variables, or even just a single global object that could be used for storing/setting/getting values between other JS patches.

Steps to Reproduce:
Currently, imagine you have three distinct parts of a composition, each is encapsulated in it's own macro and each needs a JS patch to do some calculations in order to render (eg. a head, a torso, some legs). Now imagine we have a single global input the user can adjust (eg. amount of funk in motion). Because funk affects all three parts of the body, we have to expose three input variables on three JS patches, publish those three input and use a splitter just to get a single number to all three parts.

Expected Results:
It would be nice to be able to use a single global variable within each JS patch, and maybe create a top-level controller JS that sets that value. eg. _root.funkValue = 0.5; Each individual body part would then just reference the same global variable (_root.funkValue) and this reduces the need for exposing inputs, publishing them, splitting them, etc.

Actual Results:
n/a

Regression:
n/a

Notes:
As well as making QTZ patches simpler and easier to build, this would reduce execution time too. Imagine each JS patch needs to calculate the delta time between frame renders, currently each JS patch needs it's own Time input, and needs to calculate the deltaTime between frames. With one overall Controller JS patch doing this calculation and passing the deltaTime in a global var, this cuts the execution time within JS.

Note that this request is specifically for JS global vars. Other bug reports may be asking for a non-JS global var type solution, which satisfies similar concerns but introduces problems to do with execution order etc. I would argue that as a JS developer, it is my responsibility to consider execution order, therefore I would need to know to make my top-level Controller JS patch execution first (by attaching it to a low-numbered layer) so that it updates the global variable _before_ each macro patch's JS patches.

Also consider that this technique could help encourage a MVC paradigm within Quartz Composer. Moving computation and control to a separate top-level helps ensure the individual macro parts are kept focussed on the job they're supposed to (eg. bouncing head, gyrating body and dancing legs).
result.title: Composition-wide global object or variables in QC JS patches

Mac OS X 10.6 comes with wxPerl preinstalled for perl 5.10, but it is completely unusable on Intel architectures (i386 and x86_64).

64bit Intel is not built at all, because the wxWindows that comes with OS X lacks 64bit support (see rdar://8737378). This is not a big problem, as one could still use perl in 32bit mode for using wxPerl. But this is not possible either: Executing

VERSIONER_PERL_PREFER_32_BIT=yes perl -mWx

fails with the following error:

Can't find 'boot_Wx' symbol in /System/Library/Perl/Extras/5.10.0/darwin-thread-multi-2level/auto/Wx/Wx.bundle

If this cannot be fixed, I suggest not shipping the module with OS X at all, as this might confuse users.

As a temporary workaround, wxPerl can be installed manually with the following procedure:

1. sudo cpan
or
1. sudo -i cpan
(depends on where you have your .cpan)
2. look Wx
3. perl Makefile.PL
4. make
5. VERSIONER_PERL_PREFER_32_BIT=yes make test
(this should not report any errors)
6. make install

After doing this,

VERSIONER_PERL_PREFER_32_BIT=yes perl -mWx

should work as expected.

result.description:
28-Nov-2010 01:27 PM Timothy Wood:
NSError is great for conveying the information about errors, but not so great about the extra syntax and correct usage by developers. This may be solvable with some extensions to the compiler and ObjC syntax without major language changes.

In the current ObjC error handling system, you get back both a value, which is typically testable as a boolean NO and an NSError by-ref. This means we are getting back two values when really only one value can be valid. All sorts of rules have to be made about whether you can look at *outError and nothing prevents/warns the user that they are doing it wrong other than documented convention (which people can accidentally mess up).

Consider, though, if ObjC had simple syntactic sugar for optional types (at least this one case) for errors. It might look like:

    - (@error id)doSomething;

With '@error id' being a type you could typedef or use as the type of a local variable/ivar/whatever.

The compiler would synthesize a C union return type of {NSError *error; X value;} for the type X. It would also handle the cases:

- Using the synthesized union as a conditional would evaluate (u.error == nil).
- Using the synthesized union as Rvalue of type X would evaluate as (u.value).
- The static analyzer would also _warn_ if the result was interpreted as a value on a branch where error isn't guaranteed to be nil ("Return value evaluated without checking for errors"). This would be huge.
- In the body of a method/function, return X would cons up a union with the value.
- In the body of a method/function, @error [NSError ...] would cons up a union with the error (so you would "return @error ... something making an NSError *...;" to bail.

This would avoid the issue of outError being NULL (so having to check before filling it out), *outError getting stomped and devs looking at its contents when they shouldn't and devs looking at the return code when really an error happened.

I'm sure there are holes in this approach, but I think it is worth considering and would have lots of benefits.


28-Nov-2010 01:35 PM Timothy Wood:
Oh, one other case this would be nice for is that you could do "@error void". Meaning, there is no meaningful return value. In this case, the union would _just_ have the 'error' member, and no 'value'. Using the union in a Rvalue context would emit an error from the compiler stating that the operation has no value.  Also, a plain 'return' in the code could cons up {.error = nil} and we wouldn't have to have silly return YES/NO statements.
result.title: Reduce syntax and improve correctness of error handling support

24-Nov-2010 11:39 AM Jim Dovey:
Summary:

If -[UIView setNeedsLayout] is called on a background thread which then exits, the pthread cleanup process causes CoreAnimation to run the layout process for that view's layer.

Steps to Reproduce:

Spawn a background thread and call -setNeedsLayout on a view from that thread. Then exit the thread.

Expected Results:

The main thread would check the 'needsLayout' flag and perform layout there.

Actual Results:

CoreAnimation, in cleaning up some thread-specific-data, causes -layoutSubviews to be invoked on the background thread, which is in the process of shutting down, thus causing parts of the Foundation runtime to go awry (specifically, [[NSThread currentThread] threadDictionary] returns nil, causing problems for my app but also potentially for other system APIs).

Regression:

Unknown

Notes:

result.description:
24-Nov-2010 11:33 AM Jim Dovey:
Summary:

The documentation for -[UIView setNeedsLayout] should explicitly state that it should only be called on the main thread.

Steps to Reproduce:

I have some background code which updates the content items in a subview of UIView. It then calls -setNeedsLayout so that the new items will be laid out in the next tick of the main runloop by CoreAnimation.

Expected Results:

The calling thread exits, and the main thread sees the 'needsLayout' flag and calls -layoutSubviews on my view.

Actual Results:

The calling thread exits, and in its cleanup (actually through pthread_tsd_cleanup()) CoreAnimation triggers the layout on the calling thread. Since +[NSThread exit] has been called already, the result of [[NSThread currentThread] threadDictionary] is now nil, which is what alerted me to this issue by causing a crash in my application (since I was relying on a managed object context stored in that dictionary, and created upon demand).

Regression:

N/A

Notes:

I'm also filing a bug against CoreAnimation suggesting that the behaviour of triggering a layout in response to a thread exiting is incorrect.


24-Nov-2010 11:40 AM Jim Dovey:
Addendum:

The reason for the report is that the current documentation can be read to imply that -setNeedsLayout sets a flag which is only checked by the thread running the UI.

The companion bug to this can be found at <rdar://problem/8699385>
result.title: Non-ideal documentation of -[UIView setNeedsLayout]

Steps to Reproduce:

Start any app that uses AVAudioPlayer and the AVAudioSessionCategoryAmbient category. For instance, use the "Metronome" sample app and add the following lines in MetronomeView.m, line 141:

		NSError *setCategoryError = nil;

Expected Results:
After launching the Metronome app and starting the audio, double clicking the home button and swiping to left reveals the mini iPod control buttons. They should be enabled.

Actual Results:
The mini iPod control buttons are disabled.

Regression:
Never worked for me. Reproducible in iOS 4.1 and 4.2.1.

Notes:

Summary:
Safari still uses the old-style SSL renegotiation described in CVE-2009-3555 and http://www.phonefactor.com/sslgap/ .  Safari stops connecting to servers requiring renegotiation and certificates as soon as those servers stop allowing old-style renegotiation.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start with a fresh "login" Keychain

2. Obtain a client x.509 certificate
  if you don't have a CA handy: see http://foaf.me/Tests/simple_KEYGEN_CreateClientCertificate.php

3. Visit a page that does NOT require renegotiation on a site running Apache2 and OpenSSL 0.9.8 > 0.9.8m

4. Visit a page that DOES require renegotiation, again on a site running Apache2 and OpenSSL 0.9.8 > 0.9.8m

both 3. and 4. result in normal page loads

Actual Results:
3. loads normally
4. Safari shows the error

Has never worked.

Notes:
It's been over a year since the CVE-2009-3555 was reported, and about 9 months since RFC 5746 was published.  As of this writing, Firefox, IE, Chrome, and Opera support RFC 5746, whereas people using Safari are locked out of certificate-protected content on servers/directories requiring renegotiation.

The iPad, on the other hand, rarely makes unexpected noise. In the event that it would, and the user does not want this, it is simple enough to hold down the volume button until the volume is zero. result.description:
Our OS X software can generate static self-contained web sites that mimic the look and feel of our documents. Now we are developing an iOS app that allows the user to connect directly to the OS X app, select the desired document, and display the HTML version in a UIWebView.    We do this using a custom NSURLProtocol subclass that fetches the pages from the OS X app as they are requested by the UIWebView.

The original documents accept audio and video media as attachments, such as mp3 and mov files, allowing them to be played inline using embedded QuickTime views.  The web versions emulate this by using <embed> tags.   The problem is that the <embed> tags, or even just <a> links, do not seem to work in the UIWebView if they are resolved against the base URL which uses our custom protocol.    They work if the src URL uses an http protocol addressing a web server, but not our custom protocol.    The protocol handler does get a -canInitWithRequest: call, but an instance is never created.

The custom protocol handler works great for all other files, including html, css, js, and all other non-Quicktime media types.

Steps to Reproduce:

Create a custom subclass of NSURLProtocol and use it in an <embed> or <a> tag in a UIWebView to reference some QuickTime-playable movie or audio.

Expected Results:

Embedded media and links to media using a custom URL protocol would result in the creation of a protocol instance and a call to -startLoading, and the plugin uses the data provided by -URLProtocol:didLoadData:

Actual Results:

+canInitWithRequest: is called but no instance is ever created.

Regression:

Notes:

This may be a duplicate of bug #8446587

result.description:
Summary: 

Full screen of a <video> element with an aspect ratio different than the source video will stretch to the aspect ratio of the <video> player instead of using pillarbox/letterbox

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Insert a <video> element into an HTML page something like this <video src="file.mp4" width="640" height="360"> where file.mp4 has dimensions like 480x360
2. Play the video.
3. Click the fullscreen button in Safari's video player
4. Full screen stretches the video to a 16:9 aspect ratio (matching the 16:9 of the <video> element).

Expected Results:

I would expect the video file to keep its 4:3 aspect ratio when going fullscreen and to see black pillars on either side. This would be similar to the <video> when playing in the page, as it maintains the aspect ratio. The HTML spec says:

> Video content should be rendered inside the element's playback area such that the video content is shown centered in the playback area at the largest possible size that fits completely within it, with the video content's aspect ratio being preserved. Thus, if the aspect ratio of the playback area does not match the aspect ratio of the video, the video will be shown letterboxed or pillarboxed

This is how inline video is handled and I would expect fullscreen to behave the same.

Actual Results:

The video is stretched to fit the aspect ratio of the <video> player.

Regression:

This problem does not exist in iPad's Safari. On the iPad, going fullscreen maintains the source video's aspect ratio.

Notes:

There's a good example of this problem here if you access the page without Flash installed: http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1104350651/tiktok-lunatik-multi-touch-watch-kits

This exhibits the problem slightly differently, as the <video> element is a 4:3 ratio and the source is 16:9. The playing video is stretched vertically when going to fullscreen with black bars on the side, mimicking the 4:3 ratio of its <video> element.

Attached is a short video of the above site's issue. I originally discovered this working on a video product for our CMS. Here is another example, from our own product: http://materdei.org/apps/video/watch.jsp?v=830
result.title: Full screen <video> in Safari distorts aspect ratio

result.description:
ER: provide API to detect Core Data thread-safety violation

Summary: 

Please provide some way to detect whether an NSManagedObjectContext was created on the thread that is actually using the MOC. I'd like to be able to do something like this:

NSAssert(self.workingMOC.thread == [NSThread currentThread], @"you have switched threads you idiot");
or perhaps
NSAssert(!self.workingMOC.creastedOnMainThread, @"you can't use that MOC on a worker thread");

Steps to Reproduce:
If an NSManagedObjectContext is created on the main thread and then passed to a worker thread, bad things happen (usually EXC_BAD_ACCESS during a context save). 

It's well-documented that a program must not do this. Yet I just got bitten yet again by a violation of this rule, while converting some code from single-threaded to multi-threaded. I was inadvertently creating the worker thread's MOC in the main thread's initialization (via a lazy initializer that I didn't notice was being triggered).

Perusal of developer forums and mailing lists shows that this is a fairly common error. The only tool I have to detect this is manual inspection of my code. If I could throw in an NSAssert, I could at least know that I had jumped threads with the MOC. In my most recent encounter, I was absolutely certain that I was following the one-thread-per-MOC rules, so I was searching elsewhere for the problem. But I was wrong.

Expected Results:
Happier programmers and fewer Core Data threading bugs.

Actual Results:

Regression:

Notes:
result.title: ER: provide API to detect Core Data thread-safety violation

I've discovered that NSTextView's default handling of keyboard-driven selection manipulation fails badly when the text being edited contains line ending composed of carriage return and linefeed characters. Text with just linefeed character endings doesn't cause the problem.

1. Open the attached "CRLFText.txt" in TextEdit.
2. Hold the shfit key and press the down arrow once to select the first line and its newline ending.
3. Hold the shift key and press the left arrow once to shrink the selection by one character. The line feed is removed from the active selection, showing apparently just the single line of text being selected.
4. Hold the shift key and press the left arrow once more to shrink the selection further.

Expected: The selection should shrink to consume the visible period that seems to be the end of the selection OR the selection should not visible change but should invisibly be shrinking to consume the CR character that is causing trouble.

Actual: Instead of shrinking the selection, the cmd-left-arrow gesture causes the LF to be reinstated as part of the selection, causing an endless cycle whereby repeated cmd-left-arrow gestures simply toggles between it being part of an not part of the selection.

To witness correct behavior, add several lines to the document by navigating to the bottom and Typing out several lines with newlines as inserted by TextEdit, which will default to simple LF characters. Now repeated a similar test as above, selecting an entire line of the "good" text and shift-left-arrowing repeatedly will continuously shrink the selection.

IN A NUTSHELL: shift-left-arrow should continuously shrink the selection with the direction of the selection is down/right. The presence of a CR/LF sequence presents a reproduceable case where this shrinkage doesn't work right and where a user-unfriendly cycle is introduced instead.
result.title: NSTextView key-editing mechanics broken on CR/LF endings

Mac OS X Time Machine: Multiple FAIL
By reppep on Saturday, November 13 2010, 23:33 - bug - Permalink
My MacBook Pro's hard drive died last week. I got a new 250gb drive from Alex and replaced the dead one. Good thing I use Time Machine and a Time Capsule, I thought...

FAIL #1: The Mac OS X 10.6 Snow Leopard installer has an option to incorporate a Time Machine backup, so I mounted my Time Capsule. Unfortunately, Apple apparently hardwired the shared Data volume into this client. Of course, I chose to put my backups on my personal pepper volume, not the common Data volume accessible to other users! The Snow Leopard Installer absolutely refused to let me mount pepper or restore from Time Machine. I checked, and the backup is a 750gb .sparsebundle package on a 1tb Time Capsule, so I couldn't just move it over to the volume the Installer was fixated on -- not enough space.

FAIL #2: I copied the whole .sparsebundle backup to an external 1tb disk, but the Installer couldn't see the backup. It saw the disk, but couldn't find the backup. I tried putting it into a Backup folder, but no joy. Fortunately the Installer points out that you can also restore from Migration Assistant after installation (necessary if you're restoring to a Mac other than the one which made the backup).

So I cursed a little, did a regular install, and rebooted.

FAIL #3: Apple's welcome app (loud music & whizzy graphics) can restore Time Machine backups, but again couldn't see my pepper volume or restore from my hard disk. So I had to walk through creating my account again.

FAIL #4: After logging in, I launched /Applications/Utilities/Migration Assistant (I know most people don't even know it exists, much less where, although it's easy enough to find if you know what you're looking for), and told it I wanted to restore from a Time Machine backup. Again, it was unable to see either my network or local backups, but once I double-clicked the .sparsebackup file it mounted as "Time Machine Backups" and Migration Assistant saw it. Confusingly, Migration Assistant showed the new volume as 'prowler ("prowler")', which doesn't match its name on the Desktop.

Summary:

As documented at http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/DOCUMENTATION/Security/Reference/certifkeytrustservices/Reference/reference.html#//apple_ref/c/func/SecIdentityCopyPreference , the third argument in SecIdentityCopyPreference takes a CFArrayRef of distinguished names to filter identities by.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Connect to an SSL server whose CertificateRequest message contains a list of one or more CAs to constrain client certificates to.
2. Have a client certificate identity preference, where the client certificate is NOT issued by one of those CAs.

Expected Results:
No client certificate will be returned, because it does not meet the criteria established by the server / passed in.

Actual Results:
The non-matching client certificate will be returned.

Notes:

See
http://www.opensource.apple.com/source/libsecurity_keychain/libsecurity_keychain-38504/lib/SecIdentity.cpp

_SecIdentityCopyPreferenceMatchingName, which provides the implementation details for SecIdentityCopyPreference, contains this code:

    // filter on valid issuers, if provided
    if (validIssuers) {
        //%%%TBI
    }

See also http://lists.apple.com/archives/apple-cdsa/2010/Mar/msg00003.html for more discussion about this issue.
result.title: SecIdentityCopyPreference does not filter on validIssuers

Summary:
When the user duplicates a target in an Xcode project, and the target is linking to a library in the SRCROOT, the duplicate target will have a LIBRARY_SEARCH_PATHS that has extra backslash escapes.

More concretely, if the original target has the following search paths (copied from project.pbxproj):

				LIBRARY_SEARCH_PATHS = (
					"$(inherited)",
					"\"$(SRCROOT)/FlurryLib\"",
				);

Then the duplicate will have these search paths:

				LIBRARY_SEARCH_PATHS = (
					"$(inherited)",
					"\\\"$(SRCROOT)/FlurryLib\\\"",

Because of the added backslashes, the duplicated target will fail to link. Instead it will give errors like these:

ld: warning: directory '"/Users/rbeef/Desktop/Test' following -L not found
ld: warning: directory 'project/FlurryLib"' following -L not found

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Using the Project -> Add to project menu, add a folder containing a .a file.
3. Control-click the target and choose Duplicate.
4. Attempt to build the new target.

Compiles and links.

Actual Results:

Regression:

While I cannot reliably reproduce this, there are some symptoms which I believe might be related.

- I generally use the keyboard shortcuts that involve the arrow keys (in Sys Prefs > Expose & Spaces > Spaces > "To switch between spaces"). I use the Control modifier key to invoke this.
- This is not reliable, but I have noticed the problem seems to occur more frequently when I attempt to press a Command key combination while the Spaces animation is switching. I generally notice this when switching to a Space with a Twitter client on, which I quickly press the key combinations Command-R, Command-1, and Command-2.
- The only way to restore keyboard access is to kill the Dock process (which launchd will then relaunch). This fix is not guaranteed, however, and sometimes I can only get one Spaces switch before the Dock hang issue reoccurs. Sometimes it happens, sometimes it doesn't.
- All keyboard events that relate to switching spaces continue to work normally when in this state.

Notes:

This happens to me daily on 2 separate machines (and has happened on 2 other machines), running both Mac OS X 10.5 and 10.6 variants. If there is *anything* I can do to aid in debugging (e.g. set a user defaults key or install a custom Dock.app build with extensive logging), please let me know.

I suspect the issue is related to the switching animation itself. A user defaults flag to disable that animation would likely mask the issue (as well as speed up my workflow). :)

result.description:
Summary:
After stopping a streaming source with alSourceStop(source_id) and calling alSourcei(source_id, AL_BUFFER, AL_NONE) to detach the buffers, the source will still report some buffers processed when alGetSourcei is called with AL_BUFFERS_PROCESSED.  If you sleep for 0.01 seconds, the system will have a chance to clear the source and the source will no longer report processed buffers.

A problem arises when you want to re-use that source immediately for another streaming sound. That code's streaming update loop would typically check to see how many buffers it has processed, and getting a fresh source with buffers already processed from a previous sound could break that code.

Steps to Reproduce:
Attach 32 buffers to a streaming source using alSourceQueueBuffers and let them play out. Then execute the following:

alSourceStop(source_id);
alSourcei(source_id, AL_BUFFER, AL_NONE);
[NSThread sleepForTimeInterval: sleepTime];
alGetSourcei(source_id, AL_BUFFERS_PROCESSED, &buffers_processed);

Expected Results:
Even with sleepTime 0.0, buffers_processed should be 0 since we've detached from the source. The source should be properly cleared.

Actual Results:
If sleepTime is 0.0, you'll likely get a value greater than zero for buffers_processed. If you increase sleepTime to 0.01, buffers_processed will be 0. It seems like the OpenAL system needs some time to properly clear the source for re-use.

Regression:
I tried this on iPad 3.2 and the device seems to need less sleepTime than in the Simulator. They both need non-zero sleep times though.

Notes:
result.title: OpenAL slow to clear AL_BUFFERS_PROCESSED after a source has been stopped.

result.description:
ummary: The rotation lock switch on the edge of the iPad now mutes the volume in iOS 4.2, affecting usability.

Steps to Reproduce: Toggle the rotation lock switch.

Expected Results: The screen rotation locks/unlocks.

Actual Results: The volume mutes/unmutes.

Regression: Earlier versions of iOS on the iPad to not have this issue.

Notes: 

On the iPhone, muting is an important feature that needs to be quickly accessible. The phone rings when it is called. Users need to be able to quickly mute their phones when they are in a location where an unexpected ring might disturb others.

The iPad, however, does not receive phone calls, and thus (for the most part) it does not ring unexpectedly. Users are also much less likely to take it with them to a location, such as a theater or restaurant, where this mute function would receive a lot of use.
 
The iPad does, though, see heavy use near couches, beds and laps: all places where the device is frequently held at odd angles, and the user themselves may be in an odd orientation as well. In these common situations, controlling the rotation of the device is of much greater importance.

An argument could be made (and I suspect, was) that feature parity across iOS devices should include the existence of a dedicated mute switch. However, the iPad is a much different beast than its smaller iPhone and iPod touch brethren. I would argue that a feature used much more often (rotation lock) should have the dedicated switch, and that the previous functionality of holding the volume down toggle to mute was nearly as fast, and certainly fast enough. In contrast, iOS 4.2 has sped up the muting functionality slightly, while making the rotation lock a double-click, swipe and tap affair that takes far longer and annoys at least half a dozen registered developer users that I know, when polled about the issue. (I have encouraged them to file bugs with you as well.)

Having a system preference for this setting to switch between the two functions would be acceptable, but removing the original functionality completely is not.
result.title: iPad Rotation Lock Switch Change

result.description:
Summary:

iOS beta releases expire without warning.

Steps to Reproduce:

1) Install iOS beta release
2) Wait

Expected Results:

Some kind of warning, like those displayed for expiring provisioning profiles, should be displayed by the OS.

Actual Results:

The "plug into iTunes" screen is displayed AFTER expiration. At this point, it's not possible to sync or recover any data off of the device. Oddly, it can still be used to play music using the remote clicker on the standard headphones.

Regression:

Not known. Apple has never been explicit about how and when it expires iOS beta releases.

Notes:

iOS developers are well aware of Apple's advice to not install beta releases on personal devices. The primary reason for this enhancement request is because there is often test data and other information on the device with no means to extract it. In essence, developers are faced with data loss.

There are several ways this situation could be avoided:

1) Apple could explicitly state how long a beta release will be active. Developers can then generate a warning themselves (using iCal or some other alarm.)

2) Apple could allow syncing on a device that has expired. The fact that the device is able to play music after expiration means that background processes are still running. The process that performs syncing could be one of those processes.

3) Apple could implement a warning mechanism similar to the one used for device provisioning. This would allow developers to sync and install a new beta before being locked out. This is the preferred solution.
result.title: ENHANCEMENT: iOS beta expiration warnings

result.description:
The CFBundleGetInfoString key is deprecated, but the online docs don't specify when it was deprecated or what the potential implications are, and particularly which OS versions are affected and how they react.

http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/General/Reference/InfoPlistKeyReference/Articles/CoreFoundationKeys.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009249-SW3

Several Radars touch on this issue — here are just a few:
rdar://problems/3460308&4331461&4423258&4696179&4712185&4764027&4876909

In particular, 4331461 seems to have handled this fairly cleanly in Snow Leopard, but the docs don't seem to reflect the change in a way that is intelligible to developers.

Finder's "Get Info" panel and standard Cocoa about boxes are the most common places this info is displayed.

Finder on 10.5 prefers CFBundleGetInfoString if it exists, and CFBundleShortVersionString otherwise. It never displays NSHumanReadableCopyright, so many developers continue to use something like "v1.2, © 2007–2010 My Company" for CFBundleGetInfoString.

Finder on 10.6 prefers CFBundleShortVersionString and NSHumanReadableCopyright if they exist.
If CFBundleShortVersionString and NSHumanReadableCopyright exist, they are both displayed and CFBundleGetInfoString is ignored if it exists.
If CFBundleGetInfoString and CFBundleShortVersionString exist, the former is used to show the version.
If CFBundleGetInfoString and NSHumanReadableCopyright exist, only the copyright information is displayed.

Obviously, we hope that developers would provide all the correct replacement plist keys, but in the case that they don't, I would expect that in the last case above, some sort of version info would be displayed. I don't know if this is related to "CFBundle, CFPlugin/X" or "Finder/X", but it would be nice to let developers know what behavior they should expect. For apps that are deployed on pre- and post-10.6.0 systems, having both old and new keys is important if the information is to be displayed correctly to users.
result.title: Clarify deprecation of CFBundleGetInfoString Info.plist key

Developers are often told that the best way to get attention for an issue is to get others to file duplicate bug reports. This is inefficient for both developers and Apple:

 * The reporter must write up enough of a bug report for it to be recognized as a duplicate or file a bug stating only "This is a duplicate of X".
 
 * Apple must review the bug, recognize it as a duplicate, find the original, and close the duplicate.
 
Proposal:

Add a simple method in Bug Reporter to indicate support for a known bug number. This could be just an automation of the existing process: When using this method a bug would be created and immediately closed as a duplicate of the original issue. Notifications would still be generated to bring attention to the issue as if the process had been done manually, but much less time would be spent reporting and dealing with known duplicates.

result.description:
Most first class Mac apps, including my own shipping Mac app (XXXX), run into issues with the Cocoa API where the only solution is to use private APIs.  These solutions are almost always suggested by AppKit or WWDR engineers as the only solution to customize, workaround or fix pieces of the public API.  Section 2.5 of the Mac App Store guidelines state that because my apps use private APIs, most of which were recommended by Apple engineers, they will be rejected from the app store.

I suggest that perhaps there needs to be an interim way to handle situations like mine.  I have talked to many other developers and they almost all have the same issue.  I don't want to continue using private APIs, I'd much rather have the few APIs fixed that commonly need to be worked around.  

Perhaps a roll out strategy would be best.  For instance, the 10.6 version of the app store submission process could just record and report (in detail with a strong warning) Private API usage with the knowledge that non-public APIs would become reject worthy for the Mac App Store with the advent of 10.7 Lion.  This would give Apple time to analyze the most commonly used private APIs and possibly introduce public versions of them or provide public workarounds of some other type. It would also give developers more than 80 days to find an alternative to something that may not have actually have an alternative currently.

Note:

The three parts of Cocoa which require private API usage that come most prevalently to mind are: NSTableView/NSOutlineView, NSTextView and NSTokenField.
result.title: Mac apps that have to use Private APIs

result.description:
If a developer attempts to add a Mac Bundle ID to the Mac App Store, and that bundle ID has previously been registered as an app bundle ID in the iOS App Store, the bundle ID is rejected:

"The bundle identifier you have specified is already in use. Please select another."

This leads to a quandary for any developer who has a version of an app for the Mac, and a version of that same app for iOS, and chose (perhaps foolishly) to use the same bundle ID for each.

The Mac application cannot be submitted using its existing bundle identifier, which may have been in use for years.  Changing the bundle ID on the Mac app would lead to a variety of issues such as change of preferences location, and possibly issues  integrating with 3rd party applications that expect to find an application by its bundle ID.

Changing the bundle ID of the iPhone application would probably have fewer dire consequences, except Apple doesn't allow the bundle identifier to be changed on an existing app, and if an application is deleted, the bundle identifier is apparently given up forever:

"Once the app is deleted, the app name becomes available for use by the developer community and you will not be able to re-use the app name, SKU, or bundle ID."

Sooooooooo…

If you made the mistake of creating a bundle identifier in the iOS App Store that happens to be the same as a long-shipping Mac app that you would like to add to the Mac App Store, you're screwed.

I think Apple can address this in any of numerous ways, including:

1. Don't share the namespace of bundle app IDs across iOS and Mac App Stores. This seems like the obvious solution, since it will save a lot of grief for everybody in one fell swoop on Apple's part. 

2. Allow for existing bundle identifiers in the iOS App Store to be changed or deleted without sacrificing future use of that bundle ID. (While you're at it, let us re-use our deleted app names! Come on :) ).

Please do something to address this before the Mac App Store starts accepting submissions. Developers will have to jump through incredibly bad hoops to get this to work right and upload to the Mac App Store.  It won't be pretty.
result.title: Can't submit Mac app to store if bundle ID used in iOS store

result.description:
Summary:
With iOS4, developers can choose to update the application icon badge by scheduling a UILocalNotification and setting its property applicationIconBadgeNumber.

According to the Discussion section of the documentation:
"The default value is 0, which means "no change.” The application should use this property’s value to increment the current icon badge number, if any."

This seem to suggest that applicationIconBadgeNumber can at least add on to any existing value on the icon badge, if any. However this is not so.

The applicationIconBadgeNumber, when set to any number, will override any existing badge number without regard for existing value.

So a developer cannot set applicationIconBadgeNumber of an UILocalNotification to 1 and expect iOS to increment the existing badge count by 1.

Steps to Reproduce:
N/A

Expected Results:
N/A

Actual Results:
N/A

Regression:
N/A

Notes:
Developers resort to scheduling a duplicate set of UILocalNotification with no alertBody and soundName just to update the badge icon without wiping out any existing value on the badges.

The first problem that this causes is that it uses up twice as many local notifications, which already has a maximum limit of 64.

The second problem is that this requires developers to maintain their own count internally so that they can update the badges with the absolute number to be shown on the icon.

The workaround is counter-intuitive when iOS could have just increment or even decrement the badge icon by the applicationIconBadgeNumber property.

This should have been the correct behaviour according to the write up in the documentation anyway, so I have reason to believe that this implementation is buggy and should be resolved.
result.title: applicationIconBadgeNumber in UILocalNotification doesn't work like it should

result.description:
Summary:
With iOS4, developers can schedule a recurring UILocalNotification through its property repeatInterval.

There is however no way to schedule a local notification to repeat at intervals such as 10 minutes, or 2 hours.

The repeatInterval property currently takes an NSCalendarUnit. This means that the three shortest repeating intervals possible are: 1 second, 1 minute followed by 1 hour.

Repeating by the second has limited use, while the gap between repeating by the minute and by the hour is too huge.

Steps to Reproduce:
N/A

Expected Results:
N/A

Actual Results:
N/A

Regression:
N/A

Notes:
To provide backwards compatibility while introducing the ability to schedule local notifications to repeat at finer intervals, a new NSUInteger @property repeatMultiplier could be introduced.

When repeatMultiplier is more than 0 and repeatInterval is assigned an NSCalendarUnit, the local notification will repeat at the interval specified in repeatInterval multiplied by repeatMultiplier.

Thus, a notification can be set to recur at 10-minute interval by setting repeatInterval to NSMinuteCalendarUnit and repeatMultiplier to 10.

A notification can be set to recur every other day using by setting repeatInterval to NSDayCalendarUnit and repeatMultiplier to 2.
result.title: UILocalNotification needs a repeatMultiplier property

The following workaround temporarily allows 4D.app to be run, but upon reboot it is no longer allowed:

    1. Log in as the user (you'll discover you cannot launch the application in question).
    2. Fast User Switch to the local admin account on the workstation (we always have one on every machine).
    3. From that local admin account, run `sudo mcxrefresh -n 'shortname'` (logging out and back in as the user in question will not work).
    4. Fast User Switch back to the user (you'll still not be allowed to run the application).
    5. Log the user out and back in (you'll now be able to run the application in question.)
    6. Fast User Switch back to the local admin account, log it out, and log back in as the user in question.

If you do all that exactly as described it'll keep working through log out & log back in, but NOT through a reboot. If, after a reboot, you try something like logging in as the local admin account, running `sudo mcxrefresh -n 'shortname'`, logging out, then logging in as the user in question, it will NOT work. Also, if you SSH into the machine as the local admin account and run `mcxrefresh`, it also WILL NOT WORK... you MUST Fast User Switch to a local admin account and leave the admin account running.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Restart or cold boot the Snow Leopard workstation (we've tried MacBooks and iMacs), bound to the Open Directory Master.
2. Log into the mobile home of the user in question.
3. The 4D.app is a Login Item, it'll fail to launch.
4. Run through the aforementioned temporary workaround.
5. The 4D.app will have launched successfully.

Expected Results:

The 4D.app, since explicitly allowed (unsigned) and contained in a folder that is also explicitly allowed to allow applications, should be allowed to launch.

Actual Results:

The 4D.app is NOT allowed unless you run through the very odd temporary workaround. If you reboot the workstation, you must run the temporary workaround again.

result.description:
Summary:

iWork for iPad on iOS 4.2 can't insert a Photo the way it works on iOS 3.2.2

Steps to Reproduce:

In a Pages Document (on iPad) select a photo.

Expected Results:

The photo should be inserted where the "cursor" is.

Actual Results:

Nothing happens, the image stays selected in the Media Browser

Regression:

It works on previous iOS (pre 4.2)

result.description:
Summary:

* handling of account email addresses is inconsistent between wiki server and OpenDirectory

* wiki group emails are not delivered to an account holder unless they have entered an email address in their preferences page (even if an email address exists in OpenDirectory)

* when account holders change their email address in their wiki preferences page, the update is not propagated back to their OpenDirectory account


Steps to Reproduce:

* enable the wiki server, and create several accounts in opendirectory that have email addresses defined.

* add one of these accounts to the access list for a wiki and send an email to the group email address foo-wiki@example.com

* log in with one of these accounts and set an email address in the user preferences page


Expected Results:

* the group email should be delivered to the address configured in OpenDirectory if no other address has been set in the account's wiki preferences page

* when the user logs in and sets a preferred email address in their preferences page, the new email address will be propagated back to OpenDirectory for use by other OD client applications


Actual Results:

* unlike wiki invitation emails, messages sent to a group address ("foo-wiki@example.com") are not delevered to accounts with no preferred address set through the user preferences page in the wiki

* setting an address in the preferences page does not propagate that change back to the OpenDirectory account, so other OD clients will not see the user's preferred email address


Regression:

Notes:

* if either OD or wikid were authoritative for email addresses we could work around these issues, but as it stands there does not appear to be a single location where account email addresses can be managed and that all client applications will use.

result.description:
Summary:

* when users are given access to a wiki in OSX server through group membership rather than explicitly, email to the wiki distribution list is not delivered to them.


Steps to Reproduce:

* create a wiki that is not public (eg: "Staff").

* add the group "Staff" to the access list (eg. read only), as well as adding several accounts explicitly (eg. with r/w access)

* send an email to the wiki distribution list staff-wiki@example.com


Expected Results:

* all accounts that have been added to the wiki, either implicitly or explicitly, will receive the email


Actual Results:

* only the user accounts that have been explicitly added in the /groups/staff/settings/ permissions pane will receive the email. accounts whose membership is via. the "Staff" group that has been granted permission will not receive the email


Regression:

Notes:

* this makes large-scale wiki deployments impossible to manage, as access control must be handled through the wiki preferences pages rather than leveraging group membership already handled in OpenDirectory.

result.description:
This is a feature that is very near to the hearts of a lot of developers I've spoken to and is by far the only feature I've wished for since I started developing for the app store in 2009.

Currently it's difficult, if not impossible, to understand where sales and downloads come from.  When a sudden spike occurs, it becomes a guessing game to sort out if it was the result of press, being featured, or a result of being ranked in a particular category.  Even worse, when sales have a downward spike there is no way to see why.

Additionally, it's even hard to track our own promotional efforts.  While we can track the number of people we send to the store, once they are there we have no idea if they inevitably were a part of that day's sales.

This lack of data leaves us flying blind when making decisions on how to focus our promotional efforts.

I do not see a need for any advanced tools (think Google Analytics), but rather a few simple reports that would make an enormous difference in developers abilities to understand their sales.

Developers could significantly benefit from seeing the following data about their app's page in the app store:

--

Referrers :

- Where did the customer come from?  

Was it a link on Lifehacker?  In a featured section in the app store?  Through browsing a particular category?  A link on our own site?

This is the most important piece.  Being able to know how a customer found the app allows us to separate out and make sense of our sales.  On a day-to-day basis we can steer our focus to what is working.  For the future planning, if we see that major part of our sales come from one particular source we won't be left stunned if that source suddenly disappears.

--

Traffic to App Store Page :

- How many people viewed the app in the app store?
- How many actually downloaded/purchased it?

This would allow us to see how our app messaging and screen-shots are converting.  If for example, an app was being viewed 1000 times in the store, but only had 10 downloads a day, the developer would quickly know there was a problem and missing a significant amount of potential customers.  Currently we only know the number of downloads and have no sense how many we might be missing.

--

I believe these two simple reports would make a world of difference in helping app developers make better decisions about their app store business.

Appreciate all that you guys do there.  Keep up the good work.

result.description:
Summary: The rotation lock switch on the edge of the iPad now mutes the volume in iOS 4.2, affecting usability.

Steps to Reproduce: Toggle the rotation lock switch.

Expected Results: The screen rotation locks/unlocks.

Actual Results: The volume mutes/unmutes.

Regression: Earlier versions of iOS on the iPad to not have this issue.

Notes: 

On the iPhone, muting is an important feature that needs to be quickly accessible. The phone rings when it is called. Users need to be able to quickly mute their phones when they are in a location where an unexpected ring might disturb others.

The iPad, however, does not receive phone calls, and thus (for the most part) it does not ring unexpectedly. Users are also much less likely to take it with them to a location, such as a theater or restaurant, where this mute function would receive a lot of use.
 
The iPad does, though, see heavy use near couches, beds and laps: all places where the device is frequently held at odd angles, and the user themselves may be in an odd orientation as well. In these common situations, controlling the rotation of the device is of much greater importance.

An argument could be made (and I suspect, was) that feature parity across iOS devices should include the existence of a dedicated mute switch. However, the iPad is a much different beast than its smaller iPhone and iPod touch brethren. I would argue that a feature used much more often (rotation lock) should have the dedicated switch, and that the previous functionality of holding the volume down toggle to mute was nearly as fast, and certainly fast enough. In contrast, iOS 4.2 has sped up the muting functionality slightly, while making the rotation lock a double-click, swipe and tap affair that takes far longer and annoys at least half a dozen registered developer users that I know, when polled about the issue. (I have encouraged them to file bugs with you as well.)

Having a system preference for this setting to switch between the two functions would be acceptable, but removing the original functionality completely is not.
result.title: Hardware switch on iPad running iOS 4.2 incorrectly performs mute function

Summary:
Currently, iOS devices can connect to WIFI networks requiring Bluesocket authentication.  However, the workflow is seriously flawed --- it is necessary to open Safari to authenticate **each time** the iOS device wakes up from sleep.  At my university, I end up having to key in my username and password to the same login page dozens of times per day.

This issue is compounded by the fact that, for example, MobileMail.app pops up a "Couldn't Connect To Server" dialog every time it attempts to check mail and fails (prior to authenticating with Bluesocket), and I have to click through a huge stack of these error messages before being able to access Mail.


Expected Results:
The Bluesocket authentication protocol is fairly common and standardized --- it would be a huge improvement if iOS could natively support authenticating via Bluesocket, automatically, every time the device wakes from sleep, without manual action by the user.
result.title: Natively support Bluesocket WIFI network authentication on iOS devices

result.description:
My iOS app, Instapaper, relies on the installation of a Javascript bookmarklet to be effective, because it needs a way for users to easily send URLs from Mobile Safari to Instapaper.

Many other iOS apps have similar needs:

* Blogging and publishing apps can accept URLs that users want to include in a post.
* Social networking, instant messaging, and Twitter apps can accept URLs that users want to share or send to friends.
* Task-management apps can accept URLs to be used for new tasks.
* Note-taking apps can accept URLs to include in notes or save as references.
* News readers can accept URLs for new feed subscriptions.
* Bookmarking apps can accept URLs to save for archival or search.
* File-management apps can accept URLs to download.

There are only three ways to send URLs from Mobile Safari to apps today:

* Copy the URL to the pasteboard, then launch the app and either have it auto-detect or have the user Paste it in. But this is complex, especially since there's no Copy button anywhere in Mobile Safari except the standard handling while editing the URL field, so most users won't do this. 

* Mail the link to a special email address. This works, but is tedious for users, and requires both a special email address to be installed in the user's Contacts and a corresponding web service to receive the email and synchronize with the app on next launch.

* Use a Javascript bookmarklet to launch the app with a local URL scheme or send it to a corresponding web service.

Instapaper supports all three, but very few people use the first two. Customers prefer the workflow that the bookmarklet offers.

Most Instapaper customers install the bookmarklet directly in Mobile Safari. The process of doing this is extremely complex and user-hostile, and a large percentage of them abandon the process and are extremely dissatisfied with Safari, my app, and me as a result. I get angry emails from customers every day about this.

The current procedure:

1. Send the user to a placeholder web page, with the Javascript code in a textarea. The user must Select All of the text in it and Copy it.

2. The user must Add Bookmark for that page, then tap Done.

3. The user must then open their Bookmarks, locate the newly created placeholder bookmark, tap Edit, and tap the bookmark (but not in the "delete" or "move" accessory areas) to select it for editing.

4. The user must tap the Address line (which is not labeled as such when it is populated), tap the X "clear-contents" accessory, tap again in the Address line to invoke the pasteboard menu, tap Paste.

5. The user must tap Done to dismiss the editing sheet, then tap Done again to leave the Bookmarks editing mode, and then tap Done a third time to dismiss the Bookmarks sheet.

Needless to say, this is extremely error-prone and tedious, and even skilled users often miss a step.

### Proposed solutions that make bookmarklets unnecessary

The best way to solve this problem is to eliminate the need for hacky bookmarklets entirely:

* Add a proper registry of apps that can accept URLs from Safari, recognized by an Info.plist key, and add a "Share" or "Send To" panel to Safari that allows users to easily send the current page's URL to any capable apps.

But I recognize that such a system would require major changes and is unlikely. Other potential solutions would still be incredibly helpful:

* Add a public iOS API method for apps to prompt users to add a bookmark to Mobile Safari, e.g. in UIApplication:  
    - (void)addSafariBookmarkWithURL:(NSURL *)url title:(NSString *)title

* Alternately, add a Safari-handled URL scheme that apps can invoke to prompt users to add a bookmark, e.g.:  
    safari:///addBookmark?url=&title=

In both cases, the user would be prompted by the OS and given an opportunity to decline.

These require changes to the public iOS APIs, so I recognize that they're still less likely to be implemented than simpler fixes. So here are some alternatives that I assume are even simpler and therefore more likely to be implemented:

### Proposed solutions, still using bookmarklets

Installing bookmarklets could be dramatically improved with any of these simple changes:

* Implement a Javascript method or URL scheme to prompt the user to add a bookmark with an arbitrary URL, specified in the code, like the old IE window.external.AddFavorite(url, title) method. If a web page could call such a method to bookmark an arbitrary javascript: URL, this entire process can be avoided.

* Alternately, allowing window.location.href to be set to a javascript: URL, and then having that be the logical URL added when someone taps Add Bookmark, could eliminate almost the entire complex procedure. (Today, doing this just executes the Javascript but doesn't change the current page's URL for bookmarking.)

* A less-desirable (but still helpful) alternative would be to make the Address field editable in the Add Bookmark sheet for new, unsaved bookmarks. Currently, it's only editable on edits of existing bookmarks, necessitating many extra steps in this process.

Again, any of these would be a huge help. Relevant bug reports so far:

rdar://7636942
rdar://6589436
rdar://5935641

Thank you for reading this. I appreciate your consideration.
result.title: User-friendly URL sharing from Safari to apps or better bookmarklet installation

Inspired by the recent ultimatum from Apple to upload binaries for "squatted" app names, I decided to delete one of my app entries from iTunes Connect, since I am not anywhere near ready to submit a binary.

I noticed in the documentation, and I confirmed through a test, that once a developer deletes an app from the roster, it cannot be added back again in the future. I don't know if another developer can then add it back or not.

It doesn't make sense that adding and deleting an app from the store, especially if there has never been an upload for it, should permanently prevent that app name from being used again.

Perhaps in the process of "liberating" these squatted names, Apple will find a way to make it so that self-liberated app names such as the name "Clarion" which I set free should be reclaimable in the future by the developer who liberated it.

Thanks for listening,
Daniel
result.title: Deleted apps should be re-addable by developer

result.description:
Summary: 
QCRenderer is slow to instantiate and blocks the thread for 70 millisecs on a 12 core macpro causing stattering to the rendering of other QCRenderers in the same thread.
We use -(id) initWithCGLContext:(CGLContextObj)context pixelFormat:(CGLPixelFormatObj)format colorSpace:(CGColorSpaceRef)colorSpace composition:(QCComposition*)composition;


Steps to Reproduce:
In an application that is already rendering a Quartz Composition instantiate another QCRenderer with
qComp = [QCComposition compositionWithFile: aPath];
renderer = [[QCRenderer alloc] initWithCGLContext: preferredCGLContext pixelFormat: preferredCGLFormat
                                       colorSpace: gColorSpace
                                      composition: qComp];
depending on the complexity of the composition this instantiation can take a very long time (more than one frame) causing stattering on the other Quartz Compositions.


Expected Results:
We would expect that the instantiation could be deferred and completed in background using GCD (internally).

Actual Results:
The instantiation instead blocks the current thread until it's executed.

Regression:
The problem is almost unnoticeables if we work in Standard Definition (768x576), working in HD is almost impossible.

Notes:
It's a performance bug, the app we're working on is a broadcast class real time graphical playout system that renders Quartz Compositions and we need to add compositions in real time without causing problems to what is currently playing.
As from your Technical Q&A QA1538 we can't just do the instantiation of the QCRenderer in another thread.
This is a showstopper for us.
Currently we're investigating a workaround using multiple threads (one for each QCRenderer) and rendering on each thread combining the rendered textures to a single FrameBuffer object but it sounds complicated and we're not sure that we will fix the problem.
result.title: QCRenderer slow to instantiate

Summary: Unable to access a photo's title with a ALAssetRepresentation

Steps to Reproduce:

I'm trying to bulk import a group of images into my iPhone app _with_ their associated title, and I can't seem to get this metadata from the framework. 

1. In iPhoto, have a group with a collection of pictures, where each picture has a title
2. Sync the iPhoto group (Event or Album) with your iOS device.
3. Using the Assets Library Framework to access the photos in this group
4. Try to access the title of each photo in the group

The trouble comes when I try to inspect the photo for it's title:

ALAssetRepresentation *assetDefaultRepresentation = [result defaultRepresentation];
NSDictionary *metadata = assetDefaultRepresentation.metadata;
NSLog(@"%@", metadata);

More directly, I was hoping there would be a value for title that I could request direction of the ALAssetRepresentation. I get that the metadata is for EXIF stuff.

Expected Results: Ability to get a photo's title

Actual Results: Unable to get a photo's title

Regression: This is 100% reproducible on all iOS 4 capable devices.

Notes: The app I am working on is called Names. It's an app that helps teacher's learn student names. They often have a collection of pictures (or can export a collection of pictures) where the photo's file name is the student name. A typical teacher may have 200-300 students each semester! Adding each of these names to each photo on the iPhone is tedious at best, especially when they already have the photo and name correlated. Other customers are students using it to memorize rocks, plants and even artwork for different classes, and frequently the file name is already a title for the photo. I'd like to be able to use this information without having to build my own Mac and Windows syncing app. If I could access the title of the photo I'd be all set.
result.title: Assets Library Framework: Unable to Access Photo's Title
